@Zacharie Etienne: I don't know what post of mine your response is too (because it is old and among many in this thread of 300+ comments. If you want a response, then clue me in next time, because I can't be bothered looking for the comment you responded to. Any feedback loop has limits (yes, in the sense that the total energy in a closed system is finite). It is not clear to me what you mean by an ad infinitum process. The feedback loop is in reality a continuous problem, which is modelled by the EMIC models in time steps of which there are finitely many (I think). I don't know what you are trying to get at.

@Zacharie Etienne - Monckton is the fellow (a mathematician who has been looking into climate science in recent years) who has been giving talks on this. I'd say here it's absolute humidity. It would have to be. Apparently the water vapour goes up a lot with increasing temperatures. Unbelievable? Maybe. Don't forget I'm just repeating what Monckton pointed out. I wouldn't have had a clue as to what he says was going on, but now he has pointed it out, it makes sense. He says in one of his talks that they applied control theory (which involves feedback effects) but didn't apply it correctly. That's pretty plausible, after all one of the touted benefits of science is that it is self correcting, and sure enough, along comes Monckton to point out an error, eventually. But I can absolutely understand how an error could slip through at first. Especially when scientists go outside of their field of expertise. I remember when I was in university and in lab. experiments, we'd be reading about work we had never studied before, all these results and equations we were told to use in the experiment, and to be honest, most of the time I had no idea how those equations were derived and sometimes didn't even know what they meant, but you plug in the numbers and get results. A certain amount of "faith in the work of others" comes into play, and if that work is complex, and if there isn't the time or interest, and especially if it seems to make sense after a while, there could be mistakes in there and you'd just never know it. It takes someone competent and with the motivation to really dig into the work and check it all out. Remember that science can be very wrong on a subject for a long time before errors and flaws are realized. And sometimes the only reason things change in science when the disagreement isn't so cut and dried as an error in an equation, is because the old guard with a vested interest in that way of doing things, dies out! Also, given the current political push to "fix the climate" I dare say that even if a scientist with vested interests did spot such an error, he may not be inclined to point it out. After all, if you believe it, the choice is - keep on helping to save the planet, or point out an error which may help "the enemy" who is likely "working for oil companies" etc. See what I mean? There are a lot of factors at play here. Monckton happily points out the error because he has long suspected some of the supposedly settled science here, is bogus. look up Monckton on youtube and look for the videos time filtered withing the last few months. I gave you some links in the first comment I made, at the end.

@Maximus Asauluk Here: You misunderstood and over simplified a very complex topic. CO2 is very dynamic in our atmosphere, it is depended on various factors and various factors are depended on it. I'll give you a simple human example (although I could think of hundreds of examples), if certain parts of the world are getting warmer (or colder) because of climate change, that is influenced by CO2 levels, humans will use more air conditioning, which then increases electricity demand, which then increases CO2 emissions which in turn causes even more harm to the climate. It's a positive feedback loop in this case.

One such complication that comes to mind is the fact that measuring the amount of water vapour isn't as straightforward as you'd think. Most common scientific measurement for that is called relative humidity. That's the metric used for weather forecast for example. 50% relative humidity = 50% chance of rain tonight. But what you're talking about sounds more like absolute humidity, which is a very different measurement. Absolute humidity is basically how much water vapour there is in the air by volume. But relative humidity? Idk wtf that shit is. It's like the pressure of water vapour compared to how much the atmosphere normally has or something? Weird. Edit - Oh btw who is Monckton?
@Bal√°zs Kecskem√©ti Ok thanks, but if the feedback is non-linear, i.e the temperature will stabilise, why is the title of this video "climate change is already irreversible"?

@Zacharie Etienne - "It's not just the sun that makes the natural 270 Kelvin of temperature, it's also the water vapour produced by the 270 Kelvin of temperature." Monckton is saying they are not accounting for that 270 K (or whatever the no water vapour surface temperature would be) to be causing any water vapour to enter the atmosphere. They seem to be assuming that initial temperature causes no water vapour to enter the atmosphere. Why? Probably because the math is a bit complex and if we've buried an error in there and for a long time no one has noticed it, it can be hard to uncover it. The only thing that caused Monckton to suspect something was wrong was that the modles were predicting much more warming than what was being observed, causing Monckton and other scientists to look into it to see iof they could figure out why. According to Monckton, any proper treatment of water vapour feedback estimations would first calculate the amount of water vapour feedback (the amount of water vapour able to be dissolved in the atmosphere without there being any other greenhouse gases present) due to what would be the total temperature if the atmosphere had no greenhouse gases (also meaning - no water vapour). So assuming an atmosphere with just oxygen and nitrogen, you'd have a base temperature value (caused by the sunshine). Then based on that temperature for a dry atmosphere, a certain amount of water vapour could enter the atmosphere, which would then increase the temperature somewhat, which would then increase the amount of water vapour a small amount more, etc. until an equilibrium temperature and amount of water vapour are reached. THEN adding some CO2 greenhouse gas as well, would cause some further warming of the atmosphere, which would cause more water vapour to be dissolved in the atmosphere, so a little bit more warming would result, etc. until a new equilibrium amount of water vapour is present corresponding to the actual temperature we have, which is due to the warming caused by sunshine, CO2 and water vapour in the atmosphere. So this means that the initial temperature causes some water vapour to enter the atmosphere. And then adding some CO2 causes a little more water vapour to enter the atmosphere. Each of which increases the temperature a bit. But according to Monckton this was not what was being done. He says that only the CO2 greenhouse warming change in temperature value was being used (not 270 K but something like 30 K) to account for all the water vapour feedback, so all the water vapour feedback (increase in water vapour) was being attributed to this change in temperature value. Meaning according to him that the 270 K was (in the equations they use) assumed not to cause any water vapour feedback! So all the water vapour in the atmosphere is being generated (he says they assume - probably without realizing their error) by the change in temperature due to greenhouse CO2 in the atmosphere, not the total temperature. Meaning that whether they realized it or not, their calculations assumed the sunshine caused no water vapour to enter the atmosphere, but when the CO2 was added, then THAT greenhouse temperature increase due to CO2 alone, is assumed to account for all the water vapour entering the atmosphere. But that's wrong because even with no CO2, the heat from the sun alone will cause water vapour to enter the atmosphere. So he says they fouled up the water vapour feedback calculations! The takeaway point is - when that mistake is made, the models will over-predict the amount of warming due to water vapour feedback because the models parameters are wrongly tuned, because they are using the wrong temperature term to calculate the amount of water vapour entering the atmosphere due to additional CO2 added. In summary he says that, for a doubling of CO2, instead of expecting to get from say 3.5K to 8K of additional warming, we are instead only going to get around 1K to 1.5K additional warming, which isn't a climate emergency (and may actually be beneficial). But for a more precise explanation (from someone who knows a lot more about it than me!) watch the video links I provided in the other comment. of course, other factors - such as a change in the solar output, or cloud cover, etc. could cause warming (or cooling) that is independent of the amount of CO2 in the atmosphere.

@Maximus Asauluk Right, except your example uses a human driven phenomena; the use of air-conditioning. I chose my words very carefully. I said _so long as human CO2 output remains constant_ , there must be an equilibrium. Well I'd say because of the fact we're going to run out of fossil fuels soon (in the scheme of climate change), this means not only will human CO2 output not increase, it will decrease, very very slowly undoing the effects of climate change.

@ranter7100 That's a fair point, but it doesn't change my original point, only makes it less relevant. Humans reducing the number of trees on Earth does raise the CO2 equilibrium point, the same way humans contributing more and more pollution (actual CO2), raises the CO2 equilibrium point. But eventually there comes a point where humans won't produce more pollution, in fact this will happen as a sudden drop when we run out of fossil fuels. Likewise there is an equilibrium point where humans won't cut down more trees than we grow, which would could be the point where there are so few trees that they're as expensive as gold for example. Remember, my point is that no matter how bad it gets, it must stabilise. It can't simply get worse and worse out of control forever nothing we can do. But I'm not saying it's not going to get worse. It will. But it's always reversible. As for your second point, see pascal's wager for that.

@tubewatch59 Um I don't get you. Why would the already existing 270 Kelvin of temperature cause any additional increase in temperature? ‚Äã@DMart Somehow I'm here reading this a year later. Better late than never lol. Ok there are 2 halves to your comment. I'll start with the 2nd half first, that the small changes now will have devastating impacts on the environment, which us humans will struggle to adapt to. I don't agree or disagree with this. I have no idea what the impact of climate change will be on us. Take your example of the poor being displaced by rising sea levels, what will happen? Will they become more poor? Will they all die? Will they all turn to anarchy and start attacking the rich? Definite possibilities, but I don't know. And yes the impact on humans could be our extinction or worse. But that wasn't my point. I was talking about negative/positive feedback loops. I'm saying that no matter how much CO2 we contribute, as long as it is a constant amount, there must be an equilibrium point where it is stable, where CO2 doesn't grow or shrink.¬† In other words, sure, seas and temperature will rise, natural disasters will get worse, but not forever. There will hit a point where the temperature cannot increase further. Maybe after +1¬∞¬†C, maybe 10¬∞ C, maybe 100¬∞¬†C. Now to the 1st point half of your comment. There's a difference between the equilibrium level of CO2, and the actual level of CO2. Equilibrium level of CO2 means the level of CO2 which is stable under all planetary forces (including human). A severe drought could cause there to be a temporary spike in CO2, but over the long time the drought fades away, CO2 would go back to the equilibrium which hasn't changed. And after the severe drought(s) you would get more humidity-heavy events like rain and floods, because there is an equilibrium for water as well. The only way you would change the equilibrium for CO2 with droughts is if the planet was on average in a constant state of drought, which defies the definition of being in drought.

@Zacharie Etienne - Very well argued. Yes, shifting equilibrium points are what happens all the tie, or else, we'd be Venus (which was likely caused by catastrophic volcanism, not gradual greenhouse gas heat buildup). Also see Monckton where he points out that humans have been basing their CO2 warming models based on the wrong temperature term. As more CO2 is added it causes additional heating (it's a greenhouse gas) which causes additional water vapour to go into the atmosphere which then causes additional heating (the water vapour feedback). Well guess what? It turns out that (dumb as it may seem in hindsight - but perhaps an error not so easy to spot initially) that the temperature term the modellers were using wasn't the actual temperature of the atmosphere, but an additional warming temperature term due to the presence of greenhouse gases. Meaning that instead of reasoning something like - due to CO2 in the atmosphere the temperature has increased from 270 Kelvin to 300 Kelvin causing increased water vapour to go into the atmosphere, which the - INSTEAD, according to Monckton, they've been arguing (without realizing it) something more like THIS - due to CO2 in the atmosphere we now have a temperature of 30 Kelvin which is causing additional warming due to additional water vapour. See/ They're attributing ALL the additional water vapour feedback to the extra 30 Kelvin of temperature, but NO FEEDBACK from the already existing 270 Kelvin of temperature due to the sun shining! When that is done, the predicted water vapour feedback which loops into everything else is massively exaggerated, causing the models to all predict catastrophic warming (which we haven't seen and won't see). In summary while there is a tiny amount of warming due to additional CO2 being put into the air by humans, it's not much warming, and therefore is nothing to destroy economies and lives over. And certainly no reason to avoid eating meat! In fact it's likely all political in nature, as the arguments to try and curb climate change dovetail precisely with the aims of those who wish to rule the planet and regulate it with an iron fist of control over your life. @Zacharie Etienne fair question. It boils down to the fact that the feedback is non-linear. Eventually, the amount of heat radiated out to space will equal to the amount of heat received, and the temperature will stabilize. If the feedback was linear (meaning only positive, and always increasing proportionally), then the temperature would go to infinity. But in reality it's not linear, nothing is. Eventually the strength of the feedback is diminishing and the temperature stabilizes, albeit at a much higher level, than without feedback.

A D Well, raising farm animals like cows is incredibly resource intensive, so it takes up a lot of water and space. With so many cows, you also get a lot of cow dung, farts, etc, all of which have methane. I'm fuzzy on this, but from what I remember methane has a higher greenhouse effect on large numbers than other gases. This would be bad already, but it gets worse because the more methane is released into the environment, the warner it gets, and that melts permafrost in areas like Siberia, which of course have massive stores of methane. It's too late because...it's already starting to melt. So technically, not eating meat would reduce the demand for livestock and ultimately reduce the methane they produce. But that's a bit unrealistic to ask of people in certain areas. With lab-grown meat, however, you wouldn't need to stop eating meat, and could probably by a cut of meat made a certain way (more fat, or higher density). Long story short, meat animals release harmful gases, so not eating meat over time will reduce the need for them, so people will raise less of them and less of those gases will be released. Or we should switch to lab-grown meat.

I know that you don't really care but just so you have a frame of reference things on the ppm or even ppb (parts per million or parts per billion) scale have huge and very real effects. The best example that I can give you (besides climate change) is the water in Flint MI. You've heard about the crisis with the really high and toxic levels of lead in the water. You know what the concentration of that is? 25 ppb. 25 parts per BILLION is enough for people to be getting sick and put at increased risk of cancer. Methane is measured in ppb and co2 is measured in ppm and they are having real effects of the changing of the climate.

Lots of people have told you some great reasons but one more thing to consider is feed. In the US most feed for cows and pigs and chicken is primarily corn based. Think about a field of corn, one field of corn takes a LOT of space and a lot of water (costs money and electricity ie CO2 to move it around) and a lot of farming equipment (burning gas) and chemicals (pesticides and fertilizers that disrupt already weakened ecosystems). So we have this huge carbon investment where we're making all this food for livestock. The problem is that livestock have generally a 10:1 ratio for weight of food in vs weight of food out. In essence every 10 kilograms of corn you feed a cow you get one kilogram of steak. Think about how wasteful that is, 1 kilogram of steak is roughly 2000 Kcal of food, so like one day but 10kilos of corn is nearly 10,000 Kcal of energy or 5 days of food (roughly). In addition storing and preserving plant based food is much easier and less prone to food safety problems making it easier to grow food in one area and then distribute it around the world. To move a steak from texas to NYC you need refrigerated trucks and food safety inspectors. To move dried or canned corn to NYC you can put it in an un-climate controlled truck and as long as it doesn't get wet keeps for like 2 years.

Old Frugal One Hyper-Drive Movement You misunderstand. CO2 creates a positive feedback loop which leads to more warming. You are correct in that CO2 increases lag behind patterns of global warming in the past, but that isn't the full picture. CO2 itself DOES cause warming by reducing the efficiency in which Earth is able to radiate heat. Basically, as you may have heard before, it creates a sort of "blanket" in the atmosphere that traps the Sun's heat. And we're pumping metric tons of it into the atmosphere every day. That lag you've seen in previous records is due to CO2 in glaciers and the ground being released into the atmosphere over time, but that CO2 does lead to more warming due to it's "blanket" property of trapping heat. And those old records do not take into account all of the new CO2 our modern society is emitting into the atmosphere, which adds to the warming effect.

From 53,000,000 years ago to just 5,000,000 years ago the atmospheric CO2 did plunge back down from ~1,000 ppmv to ~300 ppmv over an eye blink of just ~48,000,000 years as you've typed ("still capable of returning to the low CO2 level we are at now") as the Himalayas & Tibetan Plateau were pushed up & rock weathering increased, and "life much better than it does now" also correct. 400 million years ago free-sporing vascular plants evolved (small plants and later, trees). As there were not yet any animals evolved to eat such plants, eventually all the land on Earth was covered in trees. These trees sucked up carbon dioxide, died and become buried, essentially carbon capture. After tens of millions of years of this, the carbon dioxide levels became low enough to cause global cooling. Those buried trees eventually became oil, which we've dug up and burned, causing this video to exist.

+John Hall Climate change is a result *of* global warming. Global warming is *still* a thing, it's just not used in day to day usage because people can get the erronous impression that global warming means that any one location is going to get warmer when infact it might get *colder*. For instance the increased heating of the planet as a whole is causing ice to melt on the north pole. That in turn reduces the effect driving the gulf stream that is transporting heat from the gulf of mexico to northwestern Europe. That in turn means that long term global warming might make large parts of Europe colder due to less heat being moved there from the gulf of Mexico. Similar effects are found all over the place. Weather is a complex thing after all. But the fundamental *cause* is still that balance of energy comming into and leaving the Earth system has shifted in the direction of more staying here, aka global warming.

Then the finished product is transported from the factory to the supplier of your grocery store. Then that is transported to the actual grocery store. Zacharie Etienne. You seem to want to reduce this to a simple +1 or -1 equation, but it doesn't work that way. Equilibrium is by definition a dynamic process, like filling a lake at one end with several creeks and draining it out the other end with a river. The level of the lake can stay constant even with different forces acting on it (like the terminal velocity in your analogy, but that only has two forces that constant or heavily bounded in our world). Even small changes will change the equilibrium level, and big changes like a dam or a drought can have massive, irreversible impacts. To suggest that with this simple model the world would either be frozen (lets say zero CO2 in your analogy) or baking hot (infinity CO2 in your analogy, which doesn't make physical sense at all btw) is reduction to the absurd. The bottom line is that the world is quite different than at points in the distant path, how we got from there to here was natural feedback mechanisms over millions and billions of years, but humans have made measurable changes over a very very short period of time. If we change the temperature by even a few degrees, it can have a huge impact on the oceans, jet stream, water cycle, sea level etc. that the planet would survive and adapt to, but humans would struggle to adapt to. Just imagine the number of people who live in poverty and within 5 miles of the ocean or 50 feet from sea level. If they start being displaced, what impact will that have on humanity? How will we keep ourselves healthy and safe even if we are not affected? (which we will be because the food system will be disrupted by climate, disease and desertification).

The production of meat's impact on the environment is based on highly contingent models. And in fact, pasture lands are a carbon sink and crop land is not (in fact quite the opposite). And not all land suitable for pasture is suitable for crops (or at least not without fertilizer and irrigation). Beef methane emissions apparently can be mitigated by changes to their diet. by And more to point, plant calories are not equivalent nutritionally to animal products, neither in density or quality. And if you eat a diet that does not contain carbohydrates (which are entirely sourced from plants, i.e., grain) there is a typical spontaneous calories reduction of about %15 (i.e., people eating carbs typically overeat due to the biochemistry of insulin). This issue is not straightforward. Also, not all meat has the same carbon footprint by a long shot. There is a tendency to believe that not eating meat is healthier for the body and the planet, but it is not an obvious conclusion in either case.

On longer timescales (hundreds or thousands of years), CO2 is removed from the atmosphere by silicate weathering. As the climate gets warmer, rainfall increases and so does erosion and weathering. This acts as a negative feedback, although on a significantly longer timescale than humans are emitting CO2. Thus if anthropogenic CO2 emissions stopped now and never resumed, processes like silicate weathering would, over many hundreds of years, draw CO2 out of the atmosphere. I have heard it theorised that without anthropogenic emissions, this process would aid in transitioning towards another ice age, but with human emissions, the next ice age has likely been delayed for thousands of years. Eventually, human CO2 emissions must slow down and cease, even assuming we survive the next 1000 years, because fossil fuels are finite in quantity, and once they are gone, we have to move on to renewable (and low carbon) energy sources.

I should mention I received a reply from Simon Clark himself on another comment thread here. Since he's the go to man, figured I should repost his reply and mine for honesty's sake. Simon Clark Because it's not that simple - there are both positive and negative feedback loops. For example more CO2 -> warmer, wetter planet -> more photosynthesis from plants -> less CO2. But then at the same time more CO2 -> warmer, wetter planet -> more water vapour absorbing thermal wavelengths of radiation -> warmer planet. There are feedback loops all over the place, hence the need for complicated models! Zacharie Etienne Holy shit a reply from the man himself!! If there are both positive and negative feedback loops - that only means they would either cancel each other out, or they average out into one positive feedback loop, or a negative one. If it's positive or negative, the Earth would've been screwed from the get go regardless of humans. Therefore, when there's no human input, the Earth's CO2 levels must be self correcting , i.e. when CO2 levels are too high, the negative feedback loops have more punch, and when CO2 is too low, the positive feedback loops win over. Only this scenario would create an equilibrium allowing CO2 levels to remain stable over time, any other scenario would have CO2 levels spiral exponentially to either 0 or infinity due to effects of chaos. And if that's the case, then while an additional human input of CO2 will produce a temporary rise in temperature, eventually we will again find a natural equilibrium, because although we've increased the CO2 levels, because we've done that, the net negative feedback loops will become more pronounced, while the net positive feedback loops will diminish, and (as long as human CO2 input is constant), they'll be a point where the loops once again reach equilibrium. I can make an analogy with air resistance vs gravity. As you know, falling objects have air resistance, and the faster the velocity, the more air resistance. Therefore this is an example of a negative feedback loop, because if a falling object momentarily goes faster than the terminal velocity where air resistance and gravity are in equilibrium, then the object slows back down to terminal velocity. Likewise, if the object momentarily goes slower than the terminal velocity, gravity win over the air resistance, creating a positive feedback loop, and making the object speed back to terminal velocity. Any other universe where the object didn't have a positive feedback loop when going to slow AND a negative feedback loop when going to fast, would inevitably result in the object either coming to a complete stop or speeding up indefinitely. Now in this analogy, human input of CO2 is equivalent to reducing the object's surface area. By doing so, you'll have decreased the force of air resistance, making the object fall faster/have a higher terminal velocity. But the same positive/negative feedback loops apply, so although the object will temporarily fall faster, it will inevitably reach a new terminal velocity again, where the feedback loops cancel out and it's all ok.

This video doesn't make sense though... If there's a feedback loop between CO2 and climate, then how would CO2 levels ever drop?? If more CO2 -> less CO2 removal -> MORE CO2 -> LESS CO2 REMOVAL -> etc, then by that logic Earth would've been slowly but inevitable torched to crisp back 400 million years ago when the CO2 levels were 4000 ppmv - 10 TIMES MORE THAN TODAY!! Or maybe it's all bullshit?

If we want to effectively tackle these problems, what we need is to focus only on measures that have a real impact

1) distance tax: a tax that increases the longer the goods are shipped or transported- this incentivizes a local economy and stops the mess of goods running around the world for no reason.

2) female education- the more educated the less children they will have, as overpopulation is a huge problem

3) tackle income inequality- tax the super wealthy and the multinationals, make them pay the right share, no more tax avoidance or producing in countries with lower regulations. Big companies need the most resources and make up the biggest polluters, so local and smaller is better.

4) universal basic income so people dont have "to make a living" at any cost and follow their passions- no damaging, stupid or unnecessary work

5) make hemp biodiesel (and other biodiesels) make up 30% of all fuel compulsory in the economy and make investments. Tackle food waste and make it maximal 5% of all produced. Go towards 0% fossil fuels with improved technology. Swap most plastics for hemp-derived materials

6) sustainability index- make an index of the worst environmental offender-practices. Ban those that are not needed and bring within limits those that can be made sustainable. Use taxes to incentivize/disincentivize

Water vapor is the predominant greenhouse gas in the atmosphere and helps to maintain the planet‚Äôs temperature. As carbon dioxide, methane and other greenhouse gases are added, this amplifies the greenhouse effect which further raises temperatures. Besides hiking evaporation rates, the warmer air is able to hold additional water vapor. Warmer global temperatures, also, ramps up the rate at which permafrost and oceanic hydrates melt, thus releasing more and more ‚Äòmethane‚Äô. This further amplifies the greenhouse effect and increases temperatures that again, in turn, causes increased levels of evaporation and melting. The even warmer atmosphere can now hold even more water vapor, which, of course, is a greenhouse gas .....

Note: To read about what happens when CO2 levels are decreased to abnormally low levels, search:
‚ÄòSnowball Earth + cyanobacteria‚Äô

The trouble with animal agrucilture (& particularly, raising cattle) is not just the massive amount of greenhouse gas emissions it causes, but also just how resource intensive it is. To give you a feel for the scale of the issue, meat still makes up a small fraction of calories consumed globally. Last I checked, meat + dairy products together make up less than 25% of global calorie consumption, & meat even makes up a relatively small minority of protein consumption. Even with that being the case, raising animals takes up about 80% of global agricultural land. What that means is, we could reduce our global agricultural land use (& water use, btw) by almost 4/5ths if we just stopped farming animals.

Unfortunately, no. Nuclear is a good thing to have, but it will not be our solution to climate change. Aside from the enormous cost & technical challenge to build nuclear power planets, which many countries cannot manage, nuclear power plants take far too long to build. Even in the US, the average time to construct a single nuclear plant is nearly a decade. And it generally costs tens of billions of dollars. And we would need thousands (most estimates are in the 10s of thousands) of nuclear plants all over the world to take care of our current global energy need, nevermind our constantly growing global energy demand. Unfortunately, even if we had been building nuclear plants at break-neck pace since the 1950s & never quit, it still would be too slow to solve our problem.

Great Video, yet I have one question, don‚Äòt get me wrong, I absolutely believe that anthropogenic climate change is real, and I do whatever I can to reduce my CO2 emissions, but can someone explain to me why CO2 blocks light or rather infrared radiation from leaving the atmosphere, but not from entering? In my mind, the both of these effects should erase each other, but why isn‚Äòt it like that in reality?
Simon Clark Yes, this helps. Thank you

Great question! The answer is that the light coming into the atmosphere is composed of different wavelengths to that which is leaving the atmosphere: light from the sun is full of short wavelengths (like UV) while light from the earth is full of long wavelengths (infrared). This is basically because the sun is much hotter than the earth. And CO2 only absorbs long wavelengths of light (in a certain spread of wavelengths, specifically), while not absorbing short wavelengths like those from the sun. This is because of the way the CO2 molecule is built. I hope this helps!

Except that is really IS real: Speaking as a researcher who is working on a book that is partly about global warming, we know that the climate emergency is real, lethal, urgent, and WE caused it. How do we know human activity is the main cause of almost all recent global warming? Here‚Äôs how: 1) Burning fossil fuels increased the levels of greenhouse gases (carbon dioxide, methane, nitrous oxide) in the atmosphere and oceans. For the atmosphere, the change was from 280 ppm of CO2 to 415 ppm of CO2‚Äîa 48% increase. For the oceans, they absorbed enough excess CO2 to make them 30% more acidic. 2) We know the additional CO2 in the atmosphere was mostly due to human activity because as we burned more and more fossil fuels, the relative proportion of carbon 12/carbon 13 isotopes in the atmosphere gradually shifted towards the ratio produced by burning fossil fuels (2% more Carbon 12). 3) After human activity markedly increased levels of atmospheric greenhouse gases, the lower atmosphere and the oceans got warmer than before--just as the theory of man-made global warming predicted they would. 4) After human activity markedly increased levels of atmospheric greenhouse gases, the upper atmosphere got cooler--just as the theory of man-made global warming predicted it would: This happens because the additional CO2 we added is now trapping more of that heat in the lower atmosphere. 5) After human activity markedly increased levels of atmospheric greenhouse gases, there was an increase in the lower atmosphere of the specific wavelengths of thermal energy that specific greenhouses gases (CO2, methane, nitrous oxide) absorb and re-radiate. Again, this was just what the theory of man-made global warming predicted would happen. 6) As human activity markedly increased levels of atmospheric greenhouse gases, there was a decrease in the upper atmosphere of the specific wavelengths of thermal energy that specific greenhouses gases (CO2, methane, nitrous oxide) absorb and re-radiate. Again, this was just what the theory of man-made global warming predicted would happen. 7) Models of the relationship between levels of greenhouse gases and average global temperatures have predicted global warming with impressive accuracy. https://www.carbonbrief.org/analysis-how-well-have-climate-models-projected-global-warming 8) Research that takes into consideration the effects of multiple natural factors (sun‚Äôs activity, earth‚Äôs orbit, etc.) and anthropogenic (man-made) factors on global temperatures has found that the addition of greenhouse gases due to burning fossil fuels caused all of the recent observed warming. Taken together, ALL EIGHT of those pieces of evidence prove conclusively that recent warming was caused by humans burning fossil fuels. In terms of climate science, evidence that strong is like investigating a murder scene and knowing the suspect had motive, opportunity, you know the means of death, the suspect‚Äôs fingerprints are on the murder weapon and you have a videotape of him committing the crime. All recent warming and climate disruption is due to us burning fossil fuels. To dip your toes into the evidence, try all three levels of content in the link below, but especially see Figures 4b, c, and d in the ‚ÄúAdvanced‚Äù level: https://skepticalscience.com/empirical-evidence-for-co2-enhanced-greenhouse-effect-advanced.htm http://www.realclimate.org/index.php/archives/2004/12/how-do-we-know-that-recent-cosub2sub-increases-are-due-to-human-activities-updated/ Also see https://www.theguardian.com/science/2019/jul/24/scientific-consensus-on-humans-causing-global-warming-passes-99 Finally, it‚Äôs the SPEED of temperature and CO2 changes which is so lethal to the web of life‚ÄîTEN TIMES faster than when coming out of an ice age. Most life can‚Äôt adapt to the rapid and cascading changes that brings, and our civilization is totally unprepared for the tsunami of rapid and harmful changes coming our way in the next century (but already beginning now). If we stay on the path we are on, that leads towards the degradation and then collapse of ecosystems and thus the collapse of ecosystems, and thus the collapse of our food supply, society, and population. I‚Äôm almost 60, have two young adult kids, generally care about people and nature, and wish we didn‚Äôt do this, but we did. Happily, there are hundreds of strategies for healing and restoring a healthy balance, but we will need to switch to lifestyles and an economic model that actually obey the limits and laws of nature. That includes a RAPID transition away from burning fossil fuels and simpler lifestyles in wealthy nations (especially for the rich folks whose lifestyles cause by far the most damage). Take care.

@Lewis .Ludwig I forgot this critical bit: You said "If you say we have to do something about this, my question is what is your solution? Give me a solution that cuts man made CO2 by at least 75%. Stopping all economic activity is a straw man, but we do need a fundamentally different economy and fundamentally different lifestyles to secure the survival of humanity, and there are actually hundreds of solutions for cutting CO2 by 75%, starting with reduced consumption of both energy and material goods, and then reducing global trade and this Earth-destroying way we make things like tennis shoes. After that, here are 80 of the best researched ways of drawing down atmospheric CO2 levels (we have to reverse warming and to do that, we need to REDUCE atmospheric CO2 levels): https://www.drawdown.org/solutions-summary-by-rank The book that grew out of this research project is fascinating. However, in the past, increased efficiency seems to have fueled further consumption of energy, and we have to put an absolute lid on carbon emissions just as a family would put an absolute lid on spending. It's worth noting that when a group of five retired GOP senators and five retired DEM senators were put together on a task force to solve America's biggest problems, one of their solutions was a gas tax of 10 more cents every year, ending up at around $1 more a gallon. According to the Vostok Ice Core Records, CO2 level changes have followed Earth's overall temperature changes at an 800 year lag for the last 800,000 years. That means that our current CO2 levels are the result of Earth's overall temperature 800 years ago. World leaders have convinced their dependents that this works in the reverse order, relatively quickly, and that we are to blame, so that they can tax us out of a false shared guilt in order to be able to afford to "fight" climate change, an unstoppable natural cycle. The following is the source of this information:

Historical Carbon Dioxide Record from the Vostok Ice Core

Investigators
J.-M. Barnola, D. Raynaud, C. Lorius
Laboratoire de Glaciologie et de G√©ophysique de l'Environnement,
CNRS, BP96,
38402 Saint Martin d'Heres Cedex, France

N.I. Barkov
Arctic and Antarctic Research Institute,
Beringa Street 38, 199397,
St. Petersburg, Russia

Period of Record
417,160 - 2,342 years BP

Methods
In January 1998, the collaborative ice-drilling project between Russia, the United States, and France at the Russian Vostok station in East Antarctica yielded the deepest ice core ever recovered, reaching a depth of 3,623 m (Petit et al. 1997, 1999). Ice cores are unique with their entrapped air inclusions enabling direct records of past changes in atmospheric trace-gas composition. Preliminary data indicate the Vostok ice-core record extends through four climate cycles, with ice slightly older than 400 kyr (Petit et al. 1997, 1999). Because air bubbles do not close at the surface of the ice sheet but only near the firn-ice transition (that is, at ~90 m below the surface at Vostok), the air extracted from the ice is younger than the surrounding ice (Barnola et al. 1991). Using semiempirical models of densification applied to past Vostok climate conditions, Barnola et al. (1991) reported that the age difference between air and ice may be ~6000 years during the coldest periods instead of ~4000 years, as previously assumed. Ice samples were cut with a bandsaw in a cold room (at about -15¬∞C) as close as possible to the center of the core in order to avoid surface contamination (Barnola et al. 1983). Gas extraction and measurements were performed with the "Grenoble analytical setup," which involved crushing the ice sample (~40 g) under vacuum in a stainless-steel container without melting it, expanding the gas released during the crushing in a pre-evacuated sampling loop, and analyzing the CO2 concentrations by gas chromatography (Barnola et al. 1983). The analytical system, except for the stainless-steel container in which the ice was crushed, was calibrated for each ice sample measurement with a standard mixture of CO2 in nitrogen and oxygen. For further details on the experimental procedures and the dating of the successive ice layers at Vostok, see Barnola et al. (1987, 1991), Lorius et al. (1985), and Petit et al. (1999).

Trends
There is a close correlation between Antarctic temperature and atmospheric concentrations of CO2 (Barnola et al. 1987). The extension of the Vostok CO2 record shows that the main trends of CO2 are similar for each glacial cycle. Major transitions from the lowest to the highest values are associated with glacial-interglacial transitions. During these transitions, the atmospheric concentrations of CO2 rises from 180 to 280-300 ppmv (Petit et al. 1999). The extension of the Vostok CO2 record shows the present-day levels of CO2 are unprecedented during the past 420 kyr. Pre-industrial Holocene levels (~280 ppmv) are found during all interglacials, with the highest values (~300 ppmv) found approximately 323 kyr BP. When the Vostok ice core data were compared with other ice core data (Delmas et al. 1980; Neftel et al. 1982) for the past 30,000 - 40,000 years, good agreement was found between the records: all show low CO2 values [~200 parts per million by volume (ppmv)] during the Last Glacial Maximum and increased atmospheric CO2 concentrations associated with the glacial-Holocene transition. According to Barnola et al. (1991) and Petit et al. (1999) these measurements indicate that, at the beginning of the deglaciations, the CO2 increase either was in phase or lagged by less than ~1000 years with respect to the Antarctic temperature, whereas it clearly lagged behind the temperature at the onset of the glaciations.

References
Barnola, J.-M., D. Raynaud, A. Neftel, and H. Oeschger. 1983. Comparison of CO2 measurements by two laboratories on air from bubbles in polar ice. Nature 303:410-13.

Barnola, J.-M., D. Raynaud, Y.S. Korotkevich, and C. Lorius. 1987. Vostok ice core provides 160,000-year record of atmospheric CO2. Nature 329:408-14.

Barnola, J.-M., P. Pimienta, D. Raynaud, and Y.S. Korotkevich. 1991. CO2-climate relationship as deduced from the Vostok ice core: A re-examination based on new measurements and on a re-evaluation of the air dating. Tellus 43(B):83- 90.

Delmas, R.J., J.-M. Ascencio, and M. Legrand. 1980. Polar ice evidence that atmospheric CO2 20,000 yr BP was 50% of present. Nature 284:155-57.

Jouzel, J., C. Lorius, J.R. Petit, C. Genthon, N.I. Barkov, V.M. Kotlyakov, and V.M. Petrov. 1987. Vostok ice core: A continuous isotopic temperature record over the last climatic cycle (160,000 years). Nature 329:403-8.

Lorius, C., J. Jouzel, C. Ritz, L. Merlivat, N.I. Barkov, Y.S. Korotkevich, and V.M. Kotlyakov. 1985. A 150,000-year climatic record from Antarctic ice. Nature 316:591-96.

Neftel, A., H. Oeschger, J. Schwander, B. Stauffer, and R. Zumbrunn. 1982. Ice core measurements give atmospheric CO2 content during the past 40,000 yr. Nature 295:220-23.

Pepin, L., D. Raynaud, J.-M. Barnola, and M.F. Loutre. 2001. Hemispheric roles of climate forcings during glacial-interglacial transitions as deduced from the Vostok record and LLN-2D model experiments. Journal of Geophysical Research 106 (D23): 31,885-31,892.

Petit, J.R., I. Basile, A. Leruyuet, D. Raynaud, C. Lorius, J. Jouzel, M. Stievenard, V.Y. Lipenkov, N.I. Barkov, B.B. Kudryashov, M. Davis, E. Saltzman, and V. Kotlyakov. 1997. Four climate cycles in Vostok ice core. Nature 387: 359-360.

Petit, J.R., J. Jouzel, D. Raynaud, N.I. Barkov, J.-M. Barnola, I. Basile, M. Benders, J. Chappellaz, M. Davis, G. Delayque, M. Delmotte, V.M. Kotlyakov, M. Legrand, V.Y. Lipenkov, C. Lorius, L. P√©pin, C. Ritz, E. Saltzman, and M. Stievenard. 1999. Climate and atmospheric history of the past 420,000 years from the Vostok ice core, Antarctica. Nature 399: 429-436.

Raynaud, D., and J.-M. Barnola. 1985. An Antarctic ice core reveals atmospheric CO2 variations over the past few centuries. Nature 315:309-11.

CITE AS: Barnola, J.-M., D. Raynaud, C. Lorius, and N.I. Barkov. 2003. Historical CO2 record from the Vostok ice core. In Trends: A Compendium of Data on Global Change. Carbon Dioxide Information Analysis Center, Oak Ridge National Laboratory, U.S. Department of Energy, Oak Ridge, Tenn., U.S.A.

Revised February 2003

Here's media coverage of two very large studies published in top scientific journals in 2018 basically reaching that conclusion: https://www.commondreams.org/news/2018/10/11/save-planet-climate-catastrophe-new-study-says-put-down-damn-meat https://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/2018/jun/08/save-planet-meat-dairy-livestock-food-free-range-steak For some simple charts showing just how wasteful and unsustainable beef consumption is, see https://ourworldindata.org/agricultural-land-by-global-diets As you can see from chart 2, if everyone the way Americans did, we'd need 2.7 times more agricultural land than we are using now, and that's more habitable land than even exists on the Earth. Speaking as a researcher who is working on a book that is partly about global warming, we know that the climate emergency is real, lethal, urgent, and WE caused it. How do we know human activity is the main cause of almost all recent global warming? Here‚Äôs how: 1) Burning fossil fuels increased the levels of greenhouse gases (carbon dioxide, methane, nitrous oxide) in the atmosphere and oceans. For the atmosphere, the change was from 280 ppm of CO2 to 415 ppm of CO2‚Äîa 48% increase. For the oceans, they absorbed enough excess CO2 to make them 30% more acidic. 2) We know the additional CO2 in the atmosphere was mostly due to human activity because as we burned more and more fossil fuels, the relative proportion of carbon 12/carbon 13 isotopes in the atmosphere gradually shifted towards the ratio produced by burning fossil fuels (2% more Carbon 12). 3) After human activity markedly increased levels of atmospheric greenhouse gases, the lower atmosphere and the oceans got warmer than before--just as the theory of man-made global warming predicted they would. 4) After human activity markedly increased levels of atmospheric greenhouse gases, the upper atmosphere got cooler--just as the theory of man-made global warming predicted it would: This happens because the additional CO2 we added is now trapping more of that heat in the lower atmosphere. 5) After human activity markedly increased levels of atmospheric greenhouse gases, there was an increase in the lower atmosphere of the specific wavelengths of thermal energy that specific greenhouses gases (CO2, methane, nitrous oxide) absorb and re-radiate. Again, this was just what the theory of man-made global warming predicted would happen. 6) As human activity markedly increased levels of atmospheric greenhouse gases, there was a decrease in the upper atmosphere of the specific wavelengths of thermal energy that specific greenhouses gases (CO2, methane, nitrous oxide) absorb and re-radiate. Again, this was just what the theory of man-made global warming predicted would happen. 7) Models of the relationship between levels of greenhouse gases and average global temperatures have predicted global warming with impressive accuracy. https://www.carbonbrief.org/analysis-how-well-have-climate-models-projected-global-warming 8) Research that takes into consideration the effects of multiple natural factors (sun‚Äôs activity, earth‚Äôs orbit, etc.) and anthropogenic (man-made) factors on global temperatures has found that the addition of greenhouse gases due to burning fossil fuels caused all of the recent observed warming. Taken together, ALL EIGHT of those pieces of evidence prove conclusively that recent warming was caused by humans burning fossil fuels. @Blaise Semenya But most people who complain aren't complaining about climate change because things are changing; many are progressives who seek change after all. They complain because the current phenomena is understood to be caused by humanity and is threatening the livelihood of people as well as the ecosystem. For instance, the reduced ice in the Arctic has allowed for the Gulf Stream in the Atlantic to push farther north and shifted the arctic winds over Canada to push farther south to more habitated areas periodically, resulting in the "polar vortex." For a second example, in Cambodia droughts that are believed to be caused by climate change threaten the livelihood of fisherman who live and work in the country's delta. More sporadic rainfall has resulted in lower water levels to the point where even in the rainy season regions that are supposed to flood are bone dry, except in the occurence of floods. This means severe economic losses for the nation and the likely relocation of tens of thousands of workers within an impoverished region. And don't get me started on the Pacific nations that have swaths of territory vulnerable to rising sea levels. You might think that the environmental movement is all about primitivism and "save the whales," but honestly that's not the reason that almost every nation on earth has declared it to be a problem. It's because billions of lives and trillions of dollars might be lost if nothing is done. Perhaps I should've used a different analogy; cancer has always existed, but that doesn't mean you shouldn't stop smoking. But that's just me. Take my words with as much salt as you like.

The theoretical minimum energy required to remove 1 ton of CO2 from the atmosphere is about 100 kWh. Assuming 10¬¢/kWh, that means the theoretical minimum cost of carbon capture is $10/tCO2. The problem is that CO2 is so diffuse in the atmosphere that you have to process a huge amount of air in order to capture a ton of CO2, so most proposed systems sacrifice a significant amount of operating efficiency to keep the capital cost manageable. For instance, you don't need as much surface area for absorbing CO2 if you increase the flow rate of air over a smaller surface area using a fan, however; operating that fan uses more energy. So, sadly; no the cost of CO2 capture can't fall by 2 or 3 orders of magnitude.

Unless of-course you had some sort of magical CO2 capturing system combined with a factory that used solar energy to capture CO2 AND build more of itself out of that CO2! Oh, wait, that already exists. It's called a tree...

@Zach B that's true except for two things: 1) Trees generate their own energy and are relatively inexpensive to plant. 2) half of the energy from burning natural gas comes from combining hydrogen and oxygen to produce water. The other half comes from combining carbon and oxygen to produce CO2. So you could theoretically make natural gas plants carbon free at the cost of reducing their energy output per unit of natural gas by half.

Extinction is irreversible. For everything else there are methods to make improvements.

The many variables (human activities) that are adding to anthropogenic climate change can be managed in a way that reverses how much the climate changes in the future. Within the context of the Earth's systems that contribute towards the climate, it's never too late to transitions towards a more sustainable culture (Some, not all, monetary biased (corrupt) fossil fuel companies just want to burn all they can). However, it's taken hundred's of years of human activity (e.g. CO2 emissions, deforestation etc etc) to bring about a human changed climate, so it will naturally take many years for humans to help restore some of these environmental issues. I.e .The potential for a green economy is vast & the money some (not all) fossil fuel companies will pay (e.g. Spamming social media with fake information) in order to try and maintain their dominant market position is also vast!.

Massive problems can be broken down into smaller steps as a way to make them more manageable. Below are a few ways anyone can begin to be 'part of the solution' in mitigating human caused climate change (inc improving your immediate local environments).

1. Think of ways you can reduce your Carbon footprint that benefit your health and the planet. e.g., Cycle rather than drive (And get those politicians to invest in good/safe cycle networks. e.g. I use an electric bike, where piratical, that's charged by solar panels (or it could be charged via a home green energy provider).

2. Reduce your Plastic waste (and get those politicians to incentivise manufacturers too also). Turning the ocean (climate regulator) into a plastic soup will only worsen our environmental problems.

3. Choose green energy providers and ‚Äúchat‚Äù (take peaceful action if they can‚Äôt/ refuse to understand) to those politicians to invest in green energy deals & quit burning fossil fuels.

4. Reduce your Air Travel. Electric Jets maybe on the horizon. But until then, flying by Jet planes are a serous contributor to CO2 commissions in the atmosphere. e.g. Do you really need to fly to a business conference every year when in fact it could be an online conference & may a face to face conference every third year, for one example out of many?.

5. Eat less meat & dairy products. Meat is very energy intensive compared to Plants (inc fungi, nuts,pulses etc). Generally speaking, a whole grain (less processed) plant based diet is a healthier option and can provide all the substance your body will ever need.

6. A manageable size family. If every couple whom wanted children had no more than two kiddies then the human population explosion would be sustainable (provided we learned to live sustainably).

7. Learn more about the ecosystem you live in (More environmentally aware humans is the answer to cultures of people behaving in environmentally destructive ways).

8. Join movements (or/and donate to organisations) that seek to mitigate extinction rates. Species are dying out due to human activity! (e.g. Deforestation & land change use). Help save them!.

In summary: The general degradation of the planets ecosystems due to human activities are "reversible" (can be improved upon by reducing/reversing the destructive behaviour). Whilst the variable (effect) of increased atmospheric CO2 levels, due to human activities, over hundreds of years (net increased CO2) will take many years to mitigate, it's never too late to make that cultural/economic change).e.g., Planting huge amounts of Tree's ( already happenning in areas of the United Kingdom among others) ,reducing Jet air travel (not happening in the UK) and F.F.S!, move towards a time when the burning of fossil fuels will be an ‚Äúignorant‚Äù behaviour (outdated technology) we did in the past (before we had all these more sustainable green technologies).

Yes, but air can hold just a certain amount of water vapor. If you increase the water vapor concentration high enough or, as happens in nature, you lower temperature enough the water starts condensing, it starts to rain. Water vapor is self regulating in right conditions. But air can be virtually 100% CO2. Thats why we are focusing on CO2(and other gases like methane), as if you somehow manage to be CO2 neutral and remove the extra CO2 from air, it would get cooler and the water vapor would just continue its natural cycle. On the other hand, if you increase temperature of air enough, it can hold much more water and therefore its going to be much better greenhouse gas. Its a vicious cycle caused primarily by CO2.

@MrMichael4567 - You've put your case as to why you disagree with christianity, but you claimed my logic was deeply flawed. How? Maybe with reference to evolution? Darwinian evolution? I discussed the drawbacks of natural selection, which is the chief explanation for how evolution can replace design. Yes, I know how the theory goes. Here it is in brief: We have an initial functional biological system (we won't discuss how that arose just now, as it evolution we're talking about which requires life to already be in existence. That system then experiences a mutation. In it's DNA if it's a one celled organism, or otherwise a mutation in it's reproductive cells. Sometimes that mutation will change the DNA coding. Rarely it will cause a fatal effect, killing the reproduced creature quickly or slowly. Mostly it will have a nearly neutral effect. Less often it will have a clearly deleterious effect, making the organism less fit. Much less often it will have some kind of a beneficial effect on survival fitness. All this has been studied at length. We now know that in almost all known cases of beneficial mutations, the fitness benefit (which is a benefit that increases the representation of that mutated organism in the population) is due NOT because the mutation somehow helped to build a new functional system, but instead, the fitness benefit came about because the mutation damaged the organim in a "beneficial" way. Huh? Yes, that can happen. For example if a fish lives in a dark cave with no light at all, and can never swim to an area with light, then the eyes of that fish are subject to damage, such as infection of injury. but if a mutation takes place which damages the ability of that fish to form eyes normally, then even though the fish is now blinded by that mutation, in the environment (niche) of the dark cave, it was already blind anyway (no light) so the mutation actually gives that blind fish a survival benefit compared to other fish with eyes, because the blind fish isn't going to get an eye injury from bumping into something. Over time these fish may increase their representation n the population and may even take over the population altogether! But if the cave ever experiences a cave in, now exposing it to light from the outside, all these blind fish are now at a great disadvantage compared to any remaining fish that can still see. The point is, this is how evolution works just about all of the time. And as you'd be able to figure out, this kind of evolution doesn't build new functional systems, it only makes the best of a bad situation. To build new functional systems is not easy for mutations to achieve because functional systems are very complex and finely tuned. One might imagine that new systems are slight modifications of existing systems, but that is only true to the extent that we have slightly different variations to the same molecular machines. When it comes to building new machines, there are no easy evolutionarily traversible pathways of functional interconnectedness. Instead the various different functional machinery we see in life are isolated from each other by great gulfs of DNA configuration space. For example, if all the different molecular machines were evolutionariy related, we should observe that the DNA codings all fit onto a branching tree showing how the coding of the oldest original molecular machines changed bit by bit into other machines etc etc and you'd be able to place it onto a tree. The tree of life. Guess what, that assumed tree doesn't exist in reality. Of course, evolutionists have built many trees that attempt to link organisms and machinery, but these all conflict and do not resolve. Any such data can be fitted into non resolving trees of course, but that doesn't demonstrate evolution. To do that you'd need trees that resolve, but that isn't observed. See: https://www.sott.net/article/173647-Why-Darwin-was-wrong-about-the-tree-of-life These people still believe in evolution, but they have had to admit (since 2009) that the data doesn't fit what the theory predicted. There are even what are known as orphan genes, which are proteins (molecular machines) that do not fit onto any known trees. They are isolated and yet form a quite large percentage (10% to 30% or more) of proteins! They actually look like they were specifically created to do what they do, with no hints of evolution (although you would find very slight variations within each orphan gene family as they have mutated a little over time). In any case, building new functional machinery (including orphan genes) means you need to make many many mutations. That is easy to do, but the problem is, there are so many more mutations that do not end up doing anything useful, compared to the small number which would. And natural selection cannot aid in that process. If you need to form the DNA sequence tcgcatagcttgctacgaatcgcattcacggatataggaaccgggtggccagctcaaagc acttcggagtcttacaagtcactcagcaacctcaggcagt to get something functional that will be beneficial then until you actually have a series of mutations which can build that sequence over a long period by altering an existing sequence. That can be done, but imagine how many other sequences exist which could be built, that won't do anything useful? Of curse, some sequences will cause death, and natural selection can easily weed those out, but most sequences are neutral. These mutations are thought to take place in unused gene copies, so the mutations accumulating don't interfere with the actual gene being used (or happen in so called junk DNA). But the problem is, the ratio of functional to nonfunctional sequences is astronomically small. This is known from experiments on proteins, see Doug Axe's work: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/15321723 So in reality it really is rather like the lottery analogy. When nature is mutating a gene sequence, it does so randomly. How can natural selection guide the process? Since many mutations need to accumulate to build a new functional gene, protein, protein machines (which need mutations to link together the various protein parts that make up these machines, sometimes dozens or hundred of them) then how can we guide the process by natural selection? Natural selection acting on mutation IS Darwinian evolution (the new synthesis - that is) so how can natural selection pick and choose which mutations are going to work in the sequence ahead of time? But natural selection works by comparing different functional systems effects on reproductive fitness. How can it choose the mutational pathway to a new functional protein etc? Answer: IT CAN'T! We really are in a random lottery like situation. For ALL of evolution that is interesting, because evolution doesn't just explain slight variations, it needs to explain the origin of new function. But it cannot! There are too few mutations available, too little time to have them take place in, and too many nonfunctional DNA configurations versus functional ones, for evolution to ever be able to find them. Well, once every now and then evolution may "find" a simple protein sequence that has some effect on something else, but that is not what we're talking about. How are new protein machines that perfom complex biological functions evolved? No one knows! And don't forget, all these arguments presuppose the existence of amazingly complicated protein machines that make reporduction and life maintenance functions possible. The simplest possible life form takes about 400 enzymes and machines in order to be biologically viable. Any fewer and that life is short lived as it cannot function adequately enough to survive. @MrMichael4567 - A belief in God doesn't make us the center of the cosmos, it makes God the center (or actually the creator) of the cosmos. We then should arrange our lives around what God wants. The argument for why there is a God that created the universe, and not just the universe itself I'll go into shortly (I already have before, but I'll recap it). But who created God? The question is really this: If the universe is all there is (no God) then what created the universe? If God exists and created the universe, then what created God? Do you believe in the eternal existence of the universe in some form? For example, for the big bang to take place, some kind of quantum system enabled that to happen. Perhaps you believe it has happened many times. Some believe it's happening all the time. Whatever you choose to believe along those lines, what created the "system" that can originate universes? I take it you don't disbelieve in an eternally existing system that can originate universes (or sets of them). Right? It's logical to believe in a first (itself uncaused) cause which was not itself created, which can then gives rise to effects that are in turn causes for other effects. Logically, the only entities that require creation are entities which had a cause. It is illogical to believe in an entity creating itself. Logic demands either an uncreated God (which is an intelligent and personal entity) as a first cause, or else an impersonal non-intelligent system, capable of originating universes as the uncreated cause. Take your pick. But I choose God, because as argued previously, the nature of biology (and perhaps the structure of physics as well, but for now most obviously in biology) requires the phenomena of intelligent design (the conscious and knowledgeable manipulation of reality) to explain the origin of life, rather than evolution / abiogenesis, because such ideas relying on chance arrangements (with some natural selection effects thrown in) fall far short of adequately explaining the origin and development of the functional chemistry of life. Academia as a whole nowadays says evolution and abiogenesis are adequate to explain life, but they're not. When pressed in detail, you'll see it's a conclusion based on lots of faith with little hard evidence. There are too many nonfunctional configurations of chemicals to choose from, compared to the number of functional configurations for processes such as abiogenesis and evolution to have ever found enough of the functional ones. Natural selection can't explain this since natural selection cannot even begin to work until functional chemical arrangements have already been found (via chance mutations). See? Now we have a big problem. We first need mutation to "find" our functional arrangements first, by random chance, before natural selection can appear to try and preserve such new functional systems, and there's the additional problem that a new functional system isn't likely to be functional until there are multiple components of the new system that can all work together. Also we now know there are no natural tendencies for chemistry to pre-select functional arrangements to help non living chemicals get to be living chemicals, other than the machinery of life itself. Outside of the functional chemistry of life, nothing drives chemistry towards functionality, but there are many many tendencies that drive living functional chemistry towards non living chemicals! Meaning that only life is observed to give rise to life. And once life exists, it has a tendency towards ageing and death and breakdown, rather than a tendency towards greater functionaility! SOMETHING such as BIOLOGICAL ENGINEERING (a form of intelligent design) must have taken place to get life going in the past, because there is no known natural tendencies that drive chemistry from non life towards life. Hence an inference to God. We never see life appearing from non living chemistry for some fairly obvious chemical and physical reasons. It's logical to attribute that design to God. If we attribute it to aliens of some kind, we have to then go back to their creator(s). So we can skip that step. Here's an analogy of what I'm saying: We believe a certain person can win a lottery of the usual kind (a winner per hundred thousand lottery tickets) once, or maybe very rarely twice in a row (or twice or more) in their whole lives, but we do not believe a person can win 10000 lotteries of that kind one after the other with no break. if a certain person were to win 10000 lotteries on a row (or even 10 in a row) we would suspect some kind of cheating had been taking place. It's theoretically possible they could win any number of lotteries in a row, but in reality, that's not feasible, it is never going to happen because there are far too many ways to buy losing tickets in comparison to the small number of ways to buy all the correct winning tickets. So lets pretend we have a scenario where someone actually does win (if they could live long enough ;-) 10000 lotteries one after the other. Do we conclude they did so by luck? Or do we conclude there is some kind of cheating scheme or conspiracy to buy winning lottery tickets? I'll just say that the second operation wouldn't be called a "conspiracy theory" because there would be hard evidence to conclude there was actually an actual conspiracy. So here, an inference to a conspiracy to manipulate the continual purchase of winning lottery tickets equates to an inference to the intelligent design of chemical systems which operate biology. Concluding that winning 10000 lotteries in a row equates to pure luck, is like concluding abiogenesis and evolution are responsible for the origin of life. I couldn't agree more. About 30,000 people die every day from starvation. The primary cause is lack of access to affordable clean energy. Without energy, you can't grow food effectively, you can't cultivate or irrigate and you are at the mercy of the climate, which may not always cooperate. Several billion people have no electricity. Many of them cook food over wood or biomass fires which are responsible for respiratory diseases which are the leading cause of death in developing nations. All of these things are real and happening now, and we can fix them by allowing them access to affordable clean energy (that would be oil and gas). Fortunately, CO2 has helped quite a bit by significantly"greening" the earth and making crops more drought resistant. This (along with modern agriculture technology) has helped increase crop yields by over 25% in the last 30 years. Unfortunately, developing nations without access to affordable energy have not enjoyed these increased crop yields as much. If your motivation is rooted in altruism, and keeping people from starving to death, you will pray our climate remains warm and rich with CO2. My fear is never about warm, but that the Holocene interglacial which has been responsible for the flourishing of mankind will eventually recede into another ice age, as it has done like clockwork every 100,000 years. This means that a good portion of the warming that has been attributed to carbon had to have come from the increased solar activity, which by the way around the year 2000 was the highest it had been in around 9000 years. They are trying to fix what is not broken. CO2 is not causing the atmosphere to heat.


Earth radiates at peak wavelength of 10 microns which corresponds to 59 degrees F, which is the average temperature of our planet. Most of this radiated energy( about 63 % of the total) is centered about 10 microns and within a couple of microns above and below 10 microns. That means whatever is absorbing the majority of the infrared radiated by Earth should have an peak absorption in the 8- 12 micron bandwidth. CO2 absorbs strongly at 2.7, 4.3, and 15 microns. Most gases including CO2 all absorb in very narrow bands around their peaks, no more than 2 microns on either side of the peak.


This means that CO2 is absorbing only very negligible amounts of energy from the Earth. Coupled with that and the fact that Earth is not even close to being a perfect blackbody radiator(a perfect blackbody radiator does not exist in nature). The Earth is at best radiating with an emissivity of ..8 to .9. This means that the radiated energy of the Earth's surface is only a small percentage of the total infrared held by the surface of the Earth.


Furthermore, when CO2 absorbs a photon it vibrates over a period of time in the microsecond time range and then emits a different wavelength that is not in the CO2 absorption band. That photon has less than a 50% chance of being reabsorbed by the Earth since CO2 emits in a solid angle in all directions which includes back into space. What all this boils down to is that 1 molecule of CO2 is absorbing such extremely small amounts infrared that it's vibrations would be completely incapable of heating even a few molecules( say 4-5 molecules) of N2 and O2 around it to a temperature of even a fraction of a degree, let alone the 2500 molecules that surround it.

You are a silly chump, Simon Clark, the amount of carbon dioxide (CO2) on planet Earth is tiny in comparison with water (H2O), not witstanding the fact that H2O evavorates and falls back as rain, transferring immense amounts of heat into the atmosphere. In fact evaporation/condensation is the principle way in which the atmosphere gets heated. True enough CO2 does absorb some heat directly from sunlight (very little) and rather more from infrared radiationfrom the Sun but because there is so little CO2 the effect is truly miniscule.
Not only does water vapour absorb much more heat radiation than CO2 but (liquid) water circulates directly from the tropics to the poles, taking tropical heat with it.
At the South Pole this has little effect because South Polar ice doesn't get heated by circulating water because it sits on solid rock like the ice cap on Greenland, both caps are kilometers thick.
By contrast, the North Pole has 4000 meters of (liquid )water underneath it and, at most, 10 meters of ice, floating on top of water circulating from the tropics.
Now this 10 meters of ice is rather fragile, quite different from the kilometers at the South Pole and on Greenland.
As long as the North Polar ice is not broken the temperature gets very low (-70C?)
But if the ice North Polar ice is broken by wind or Russian ice breakers, water at about +4deg. C comes through the cracks and, wonder of wonders, the local temperature rises to +4deg. C!
This has an enormous effect on the surface temperature and completely changes the local climate, or even the North Polar climate if the break up is big enough i.e. if the wind is strong enough.
You may well agree that CO2 is not 'a climate change' villain!

@cumberland Gapgap what we are saying is the same thing. water is the main green house gas, no doubts on that. the topic is different though. we are not talking about short term climate changes; these are probably not influenced by the change in composition of the CO2. though, climate change and global warming are phenomena that affect the earth's climate on a scale of thousends of years. so while water condenses and evaporates fast determining quick climate changes, on a bigger time scale it acts just as a feedback related to the energy input caused by non condensing greenhouse gasses. to have a deeper understanding of this i highly recomend you to read the article "The role of long-lived greenhouse gases as principal LW control knob that governs the global surface temperature for past and future climate change" by ANDREW A. LACIS.

@gio garo13 I know very well that CO2 absorbs energy in the infrared but water is very many times efficient at transferring the Sun's heat into the atmosphere, it does this through evaporation/condensation. This evaporation works almost as well on land, the exceptions being deserts. So vitually the whole planet is directly influence by this evaporative heat exchange (water evaporates at night too.) I have yet to see a mainstream sources e.g. Met. Office, UN/IPCC etc. do not even consider this water effect, only making a case about (relaively) microscopic amounts of CO2. Madness, don't you think?

@cumberland Gapgap well co2 concentration in the atmosphere is very low compared to water's, that is correct. BUT not all greenhouse gasses (GHG) are the same. they can divided in two main cathegories 1)condensing gasses, such as water, and 2)non condensing, such as co2. it is fundamental to anderstand the role of non condensing GHG in comparison to the ones that condense to define the problem of global warming. you don't have to believe my word. i'll be glad to show you planty of scientific articles that explain this in detail.
