Short memories and incorrect models.

‚Äã@JMAC LIVES ... Once again, even if you've seen an increase in biomass, *carbon concentration is still increasing*. So clearly there's a lag between uptake, don't you think? And again, that 'lag' is made all the more worse by, oh, I don't know, *decomposition*! That link does nothing to 'invalidate' the model. What on earth do you think the uptake is going to be in 50 years? All of a sudden we go from 500ppm (at current production amounts) to, bam, 250 in the span of, what, 10 years? 100? 1000? Cause if it's 1000+, you're kinda confirming everything this paper says. And you're right, nothing I'm saying is new. And you have seen this 25 years ago. Because the IPCC reports from ~20 years ago (and the science leading up to it) have remained remarkably constant since then. None of this is new. As for the Vostok papers, what, are you pointing to ice core samples? Have you ever noticed that nearly all of those papers show atmospheric ppm <300 during the past 400k years? And we're above 400 today? And you think that's the kind of thing that will have a short halflife in the atmosphere?!

@Killua2001 C02 CAN actually make plant volume double, depending on the plants. Soy for example, doesn't experience C02 saturation until just under 2000ppm. Pine trees, for example - will consume all the C02 you'll give them until they run out of soil fertility to support the growth. Did we see an uptick of 140% plant growth coinciding with c02 increase? Well that's something NASA is trying to figure out (see below). The surface of the planet is certainly greener than it was just 20 years ago. I'm not trying to argue about carbon sequestration of geoligic timescales; it can clearly happen immediately and over large timescales - what I'm trying to establish is that the science is not at all settled; and there are many reasons why the existing models have not bourne out to date. I've tracked most climate articles through the mid ninties. Scientists continue to get it wrong. I'm not even trying to argue that there is a DIRECT correlation to plant growth and atmospheric C02, but there is clearly a correlation that has yet to be calculated. In regards to what exactly causes upswing in C02, and it's bering on the climate at large - have you read the Vostok papers and resultant reviews? They can only correlate temperature change to C02 within 1000 years' accuracy. I've seen your type of arguments literally 25 years ago. What you're saying is nothing new. The models will continue to be incorrect until they can establish all the predominant variables - and then predict outcomes. The 'climate scientists' have failed to do so time and time again. https://www.nasa.gov/feature/ames/human-activity-in-china-and-india-dominates-the-greening-of-earth-nasa-study-shows

‚Äã@JMAC LIVES And I'm telling you THAT ISN'T SEQUESTRATION. We've increased the atmospheric content from 250ppm to 410ppm, and yet biomass hasn't grown by 140% in the past 100 years. Those extra gigatons of CO2 weren't taken out of the atmosphere, these are not slow processes, they have tens of thousands of years of decay timelines. The model isn't incorrect, you're just expecting a different result than reality provides. CO2 doesn't magically make plant volume double, doubling CO2 won't double biomass or sequester more than we're putting out except over incredibly, incredibly long geologic timescales.

@Killua2001 I am completely aware of everything you've stated; what I'm saying is that the model does not assume the requisite uptick in plant growth; or any sort of adaptation for carbon sequestration from flora and fauna. The model is incorrect.

Plants do not sequester carbon fully. If you go through the literature on the "bern simplified climate model" you'll find some great information, and there was a 2018 paper on it with a great figure on page 10 showing the land uptake. But put simply, think about the basic processes involved. What are fossil fuels? How do plants sequester carbon? When a tree or animal dies, their body decomposes. It's food for microbes that undergo respiration, releasing CO2. Thus, when plants take up CO2, they more often than not release it after they die. Fossil fuels are created over *millions* of years. They're created on geologic time scales. They require biomass to be trapped by geologic structures, and undergo incredible pressure to turn into a 'fuel'. That's not a very fast process to sequester anything. Limestone formations sequester carbon faster than that. When the process of sequestering requires "changing the chemical composition of biomass to inorganic rock", you can be sure that will operate on very long timescales.
Why do Susan's conclusions directly contradict the historical evidence provided in the Vostok study? She does not address this evidence.

In the past 100 years - scientists, journalists and pundits alike all claim either an upcoming iceage or upcoming unstoppable warming; neither of which bear out.  ... This is a lie. Fed to you by conservative press, arguing on behalf of the fossil fuel industry. Truth of the matter is very few scientists ever spoke about an "ice age", although there were some National Geographic and Newsweek articles citing a minority of scientists because "scientists claim the earth will have a new ice age" sells. The actual scientific community at the time was not arguing or warning about an ice age. Global warming, on the other hand, you're right, the science goes back OVER 100 years. CO2's greenhouse effect has been known for a while, so yeah, even in 1896 we had scientists talking about this. Which brings me to the next point. "Why are the predictions and the models so consistently incorrect?" Astoundingly, they aren't. In 1896 Svante Arrhenius predicted that doubling CO2 concentrations would produce warming of 5-6 C. In 1896. Well in 1896 CO2 concentrations were roughly 250ppm, we're at 410 today. If we take A1B, emissions will peak in 2050, putting us on track for about 500ppm by then, and ~700 by the end of the century. I'm trying to think positive but whatever. Following A1B, we're on track for 3 degrees C above 2000s levels by 2100. Which is, roughly, 1-1.5 degrees C above the temperature in 1900. Thankfully, because this model has peak emissions in 2050, by 2300 the model doesn't see warming higher than 4 degrees above 2000s levels. Was his prediction, made in 1896, perfect? No. But given it was 1896, well before the advent of computers, I think we can cut the guy some slack. If, however, you went with models from roughly the 1990s or later, like the original IPCC report... you'll find their predictions are pretty damn accurate indeed. We've gotten better in the past 100 years. "Isn't the point of performing scientific analysis to predict outcomes?" I mean, yes, but that doesn't mean every problem is easy. We still have a hard time predicting the outcome of fluid dynamics. But it'd be a mistake to say we know less about fluids today than we did over a hundred years ago when the Navier Stokes Equations were created. "Why are you so sure of yourself, and why does everyone think tax on an essential will deliver us from climate change and actual pollution?" I was unaware that fossil fuels are necessarily 'essential'. No one thinks that a carbon tax will solve climate change. This video explicitly is about how climate change is irreversible. How these effects are going to last in our environment for a long time. But you know what a carbon tax might do? Help us get to peak carbon by 2050 and let me keep using the predictions of A1B, because it's the most likely outcome given humanity's tendencies. You know what I want to avoid? A1FI. Because there the predictions start looking a whole lot more "oh. Look. We're in danger of causing a Permian-extinction like event". A1FI is scary. Very scary. Incredibly scary. That's where these 'doomsday' predictions all come from. It's from models where we say "what happens if we don't get our act together at any point in time". And they're terrifying. Most predictions aren't A1FI. Most predictions think "we're not that stupid". I really, really, sincerely hope they're right.

People need to understand that the lifespan and exsistance of life on the earth are wholly dependent upon the ageing of the sun. Scientifically in about 5 billion years from now, the sun is going to reach a point where its core can no longer sustain the nuclear fusion as it has been and it will evolve into a red giant. A red giant star is a dying star in the last stages of stellar evolution. Therefore, that means the sun could grow large enough to engulf the earth as well as our nearby planets, but even if it doesn't, life will still cease to exist on earth at some point during the sun's transformation into a red giant. Computer models are not science. They reflect assumptions made and are very very vulnerable to being tweaked to produce results to fit in with the underlying aspirations of those creating and using them. The only way that they can have any authority is if they are tested against real world results, which in this case is tricky because none of us will be around in the year 3000 to verify the extent to which the climate has changed and/or levels of CO2 created by man's activities now remain in the atmosphere that long.

Almost all the climate change models assume that there will be positive feedback loops that increase the amount of warming created by CO2 by a factor of 3 or 4 or more. I cannot find any empirical evidence that that is the case and have seen respectable scientists suggest that the reality is more like a negative dampening effect of about 0.5. The argument will rage on, but regardless, trying to use a model to predict things out to the year 3000 is a waste of time and money.

Climate scientists are the reason you know that half fact. Its called a feed back loop, and they understand it well. Several times in the historic record, temperature changes starting rising before the CO2. (Not every time.) The CO2 increase then caused more heat to be trapped, increasing the temperature. For example, rising temperatures enable permafrost to thaw out. We see this happening right now. Thawing permafrost allows all of that dead vegetation to decompose to methane and CO2. That doesn't change what the CO2 does. It helps retain heat. There have been several instances of CO2 increases driving the heat increase. But nothing like today. There has never been a time when the atmosphere's composition has changed as rapidly as it is right now. In the past, life has had time to adjust to the change - many things still went extinct, but species and populations did get a chance to evolve. This current change is hundreds of times or thousands of times faster than any recorded change - even the dinosaur killing meteor had a slower overall effect on the atmosphere's composition. It is very easy to understand why - we are taking carbon that has been sequestered under the earth for millions of years and converting it to CO2 in our atmosphere. We know how much - the world's use of fossil fuels is well documented and accounted for. You don't need to imagine any other source - this accounts for the increases in temperature that have been measured in many different ways by many different independent people. I have days of pure desperation thinking about the state of the Earth all the time and then I try to find solace in the fact that I have very little control over this crisis. I don't eat animal products anymore, I don't take airplanes anymore, I eat locally produced seasonal food, I'm not having children and I always vote for a very green party. As an individual, there's not that much more I can do. So, I try to say to myself: "I'm doing what I can. Us humans are amazing at adapting. Perhaps things won't be as bad as we think they're going to be. People could maybe create new technologies that could make everything much easier." At the same time, I try to be realistic in my choices which is why I'm not having children. They're not only bad for the environment, but they'd likely have a very difficult life in the next century. I want to spare them the pain of possibly living on a planet where most lifeforms will have increasingly difficult lives.

8:30 No. 1 is "Don't eat meat"? But I'm an omnivore! More importantly for the science: 99.99% of livestock carbon is atmospheric carbon (via the plants they eat) and if the cows didn't eat the plants, most of that plant carbon would return to the air anyway, via decomposition and fire. Our climate problem is CO2 from fossil fuel burning: without human action that geological carbon would not enter the atmosphere but would remain underground for millions of years.

Blaming meat consumption for global warming is therefore just wrong; it's like blaming it on our own farts and respiration, all part of the short-term C cycle. Worse, it plays right into the hands of people who like to shout "Look, they want to outlaw your burger!".

So please let's stop this nonsense now. Yes, we should feed cattle seaweed to reduce methane emissions. Yes, we should consider eating less beef for an host of other reasons (health, energy, water, and land use, deforestation, to reduce animal suffering) -- but we should NOT muddy the waters by listing cows as a major cause of global warming. That's just a Cowspiracy Theory (pun intended).

@Simon Clark It is a government bureaucracy that cloaks itself in the mantle of science. Its admitted goal is to support policy makers and is funded by the same. The key word is intergovernmental. IPCC over many years has made many dire predictions which have not come true and seem to be designed to create panic and ill conceived emergency action by governments. There are many well qualified scientists that do not agree with the IPCC reports and predictions and many have created videos far more compelling than yours. For example, there is the NIPPC which is the Nongovernmental International Panel on Climate Change to name but one source. Science is not a consensus game.

@James Chambers yes, it is a scientific organisation - its reports are written by hundreds or thousands of scientists from all over the world. The end document is a summary _for_ policymakers, not _by_ summary makers. Political bias does not come into the conclusions of it. If anything, most scientists would say that the IPCC is too conservative with its projections - THAT is its major flaw. And yes, when thousands of scientists all look at the same data sources (independent data sources, I should add) and draw the same conclusions, with a few exceptions on details, that indicates that the science is settled. There are error bars due to the exceptions, but the consensus based on data holds as fact. That is simply how science works.

@Simon Clark Consensus is not science. The IPCC is an Intergovernmental panel report but is not a scientific research body per se. It has an agenda and ,many of its projections have failed over the years. There are many other videos by other PHD's that dispute the data and projections by the IPCC and other political organizations. And the research shown for taking Co2 out of the atmosphere actually turns it into fuel which in turn doesn't emit co2 when burned so we could immediately skip production of EV's with their highly toxic batteries and start turning co2 into fuel that can be used by any petrol or diesel car driving today without any modifications needed.

We might get lucky though, sun activity is very slowly decreasing (we should be getting closer and closer to a drop in sun's activity that would normally cause an ice-age), so the results might vary. To be honest, the main argument against pumping CO2 into atmosphere is "we cannot forsee how will the ecosystems change, so better stop doing that to avoid something potentially catastrophic" rather than "we know for sure, that this, that and that will happen if we raise temperatures by X".

Still, reducing emissions is a reasonable thing to do, but I kinda hate when people say "scientists predict", when the overall system is so complex, that in long time period almost anything can happen, if you tweak the parameters just slightly, and even a small error might compound into huge difference. There is so much we do not know about climate in general, that we can only make rough predictions like "oceans will rise" and "the areas of low habitability will cover greater extent of the earth, widening deserts".

When it comes to getting CO2 out of the atmosphere, the cost needs to go to the level of proposed emission taxes. I believe currently the suggested level is no more than 30 Euros per tonne, so if we bring down the average cost to this level then it might become viable. But it is true that right now it is prohibitively expensive.

You had me until the "Don't eat meat." Livestock have a symbiotic relationship with the land. Chickens, geese, cows, pigs... are not what is causing global warming/climate change. Humans are. If you revisit the graphs of how CO2 emission increased after the industrial age, you might take into consideration that livestock did not contribute to coal entering the atmosphere, electricity being discovered, and the combustion engine becoming the replacement for the steam engine. If you REALLY think about it. Animal Husbandry has been around since cavemen thought of an easier way to hunt. The graph is pretty level until the Industrial age arrives. A more clever way of eliminating the CO2 from the atmosphere is to stop using things with electricity that are not powered by solar or wind generated power plants. Another clever way is to stop using an automobile and stop purchasing things that are not local to your own community. Meat isn't the problem. Animals have been on the planet just as long as humans.

Another issue that needs to be considered with trying to offset emissions is permafrost thawing. The thawing of the permafrost will produce amounts of carbon that will dwarf our emissions and will not be anything we can control. That also has to include methane release from the Arctic when the permafrost thaws that is the cap for massive amounts of methane hydrates off the Siberian coast as well as the methane produced by the decomposition of organic matter frozen within the permafrost under anaerobic conditions. The permafrost is thawing now at the temperature level we are currently at. It will thaw even faster under higher temperatures which will produce an unstoppable abrupt change in the climate that reinforces itself with no emissions by human activity.
So... Spend the carbon tax preparing for the inevitable by moving to higher ground and floating city's or raising houses.

When you add heat to the earth, the ice melts. After the mwp, there was a 500 year period where a lot of the energy from the sun was lost due to something reflecting the energy back. When a battery charges goes down, the chemicals in the batter change. When the earth loses heat, the water freezes. When the battery is recharged, the chemical change again, to ones that can hold the charge. When the earth warms the ice melts. The sun is giving us more or less then same energy it has for the last 2000 years. About 1500 years ago, something happened that reflected the suns energy away from the earth surface. This meant that when the summer sun tried to melt the ice, there was not enough energy to do so, at least not as much as had laid down the previous winter. This meant the glaciers expanded. The suns energy was the same, it just could not reach the land. Then 350 years ago, the cause (choose which of several possibilities, but the evidence said it was there) of the reflection stopped and the earth received more energy. The ice no longer built up but instead the heat melted more ice than the winter snows could deposit. At the same time (little ice age), the ocean lost energy to space when water was vaporized and the energy radiated into space. Because what every was reflecting the sun's energy was above the oceans as well, they stopped getting the energy that they needed to replace that lost to the vaporization and they cooled. Then when the cause disappeared, the ocean began to receive more energy and they began to warm. Since both of these are part of the earth, their temperatures is included in that average.

I had written out a lengthy comment to your video without having actually watched it. A mistake I hope no one else here is making, but something tells me many will. I guess the problem is still that many will take the title of this video and many of the news we are getting as "just give up" - and we can't. Not now and not ever. We will need to do whatever is possible in terms of science, implementation, and activism. Money cannot be a factor, shouldn't be if all of our lives and the life of the planet are at stake. Money is a human construct. So why is there even a price on removing carbon from the atmosphere? Who is making that price? And in the light of what is at risk, what is stopping us from demanding that there be none? Who will benefit from all that money and why isn't the planet more important to them? Let's face it, if it wasn't for money and human greed, we wouldn't be in this mess to begin with.

I know that you are a scientist, so you don't deal with the personal aspects of this quite as much in light of the big picture, but as individuals, we can do more than just stop eating meat and taking the bus. I think that for scientists and those who can make it happen, carbon removal without a price tag should be the goal. For the rest of us, protesting and boycotting the corporations that are responsible for most of our CO2 waste - and thus making them change - is the answer.

Don't just take the bus: Take the bus AND both boycott and protest car and fuel companies. Make it crystal clear to them that without you, the consumer, nothing goes. That they would be poor without you, because money is the only language they understand.
However, we know the truth: That life is what truly matters, and that everything else is secondary, especially money.

1. "Entire nations will be wiped off the map by rising sea levels by theyear 2000" The quote was made by Noel Brown, an official at the UN, and it was an indirect quote as far as I can see. However, you seem to misrepresent the indirect quote because you replace the word "could" with "will," and you leave out "if global warming is not reversed" between the words "levels" and "by," thus implying that (1) there is not stopping it and that (2) such a catastrophic event will occur by the year 2000 rather than sometime later after 2000 if no great action is taken by 2000. As this video demonstrates, climate change is pretty much irreversible, so he's not wrong if he did say that since there is still much time to find out, and as Dr. Hansen said, there has been more goals than actions. That said, Noel Brown is not the best source of information. 2. "Or that one time 10 years ago when NASA scientist James Hansen said that Obama only had 4 years to fix it..." The quote by Dr. Hansen is misleading. He made it right before Obama's inauguration, so Dr. Hansen was referring to Obama's term in which he can take action, and it wasn't a climate prediction. Dr. Hansen has since been quite critical of Obama because of Obama's lack of great action, and he will talk about it in his upcoming book. 3. "Or that one time in 1972 when they warned us for global cooling (Yes, you read that right, go look it up)" Who is they? Scientists aren't some infallible monolithic being and they can mean 1 person or 1000 persons, so it's important to specify who. That said, most of the papers published during that time predicted warming. For more information, take a look at this paper: http://ams.confex.com/ams/pdfpapers/131047.pdf 4. "Or what about before that, in the 1950s when there was the global warming scare again?" Since this was a "scare," it probably isn't very reliable. How about taking a look at the papers published during that time. eg. http://www.rescuethatfrog.com/wp-content/uploads/2017/02/Plass-1956e.pdf 5. I didn't watch this all the way through, I was anticipating more. While you are correct that the climate change is locked in, what you fail to mention is that in the year 3000, life as we know it will have been LOOOOOONNNNNGGG gone.

The Arctic ice might last until 2022.......but, probably not. Once that ice is gone, it is going to alter the jet stream in strange ways. While they don't know, or can't say how exactly it's going to react, the best guess is that it's going to shift it's center of rotation to be over Greenland, instead of the North Pole. This will be because at that point, Greenland will become the coldest point of the northern hemisphere, and.....well...heat always, flows from warm to cold, so, logically, once the Arctic ice is gone, and is warmer than Greenland, the jet stream will shift its center of rotation around Greenland. Makes sense to me. This of course will only be during the time that the Arctic is actually warmer than Greenland, which will be for a very short period of time, the first time it goes ice free, but will last longer and longer each year, until it's eventually ice free year round, which will likely be around ten years after the first blue ocean event.

What that will mean for our crops, is most likely disaster, on a global scale. No matter where you grow crops, if it's too hot, too cold, too wet, or too dry, that is the end for your crops. The jet stream is already completely messed up. Once it shifts its rotation center, the weather is likely to be even more crazy than it already is......to say the least.

Who knows? It could even everything out, and make perfect weather everywhere! They don't know.....that's pretty much impossible to predict. But, they do know it's going to change things, likely in a largely unfavorable way, and it's going to happen very, very soon.

Obviously you have no clue what caused the Holocene maximum. The planet goes though what is called the Milankovitch cycle. This is where the earth is in the best position of the earth to receive the most energy. That means it is closest to the sun and at the best angle for the earth to absorb energy. During the Holocene maximum, the southern pole was pointed in the right direction to receive the most heat BUT it was farther away from the sun. So yes, it received less energy than it would now. BUT the over all effect is that we got 3% more energy year¬†round than we do now. In 5000 years, we will get 3% less energy year round than we do now. THAT will put us in a full blown glaciation. That might be true of radioactive waste in Europe but not of waste in the US. Light water nuclear reactors that use solid uranium oxide fuel rods can only use about 0.5% of the uranium in the rods before becoming structurally unsound, this is because a Xenon isotope is one of the products and being a gas, it requires much more volume than it's predecessors and hence form gaps and fissures within the fuel rods. The plan was to remanufacture these fuel rods back into solid rods for further use and Europe did build these remanufacturing plants but due to anti-nuclear pressure in the States, the Carter administration cancel the US remanufacturing plant. This means that in the US, the nuclear waste is almost entirely unused uranium and other transuranic isotopes with half lives well in excess of 30,000 years. These products are less radioactive than the actual byproducts of fission but must be isolated from the environment for well over 30,000 years while the actual byproducts of fission, not only are less voluminous but only need be isolated for about 350 years. Also, CO2 capture presumed that the CO2 would stay in the reservoirs they are pumped into and there are indications this does not happen. Microfissures particularly from fracking allows the CO2 to leak back into our environment, this has been measured particularly in ground water and there is a company employing passive seismic to try and map the microfissures. What carbon remains sequestered are the ones that react with the surrounding minerals forming stable carbonates. A more reliable carbon sequestration method would be biochar where only the carbon is sequestered but of course industry does not like the idea of using energy to liberate oxygen from the carbon when their whole point was to liberate energy by allowing oxygen to react with the carbon in the first place. I would agree that even with cessation of fossil fuel use, climate change would not half and indeed we may have already exceeded the interglacial metastability so the climate may just progress to a warmer state on natural positive feedbacks such as permafrost and clathrate meltings but I would suggest that technical methods of addressing the situation could be more dangerous than climate change itself hence not only are a Deus ex machina technical solution unlikely but quite risky. I do agree that we have to pursue conservation and a shift to carbon free technologies to at least mitigate the situation which seems to be your intended statement however, I'm not willing to give up meat in my diet, perhaps suitable imitations of meat or bioprinted meat. We've been able to bioprint a beating mouse heart with a modified inkjet printer (Woods Institute) so shouldn't a bioprinted steak or chicken breast be possible...

Transportation could technologically be carbon free without replacing a single vehicle. Fuels suitable to replace gasoline and diesel are obviously available from biologic sources but actual gasoline and diesel could readily be synthesized from syngas, a mixture of hydrogen and carbon monoxide gases and indeed this is done in our refineries to improve the quality of the product produced. However, just as it takes energy to liberate hydrogen from water, it takes energy to liberate carbon monoxide from carbon dioxide and that energy would have to be from a clean source. However, the claim to an environmentally friendly transportation through EV's and hydrogen fueled vehicles are just as possible with existing vehicles and fuel delivery infrastructure. It's just that auto manufacturers could invite more consumer sales with EV's and hydrogen fueled cars while carbon neutral fuel processes would only increase costs for refineries and compete with their core business model of fossil sourced feedstock. Batteries, and hydrogen are just chemically stored energy just as gasoline and diesel are. The problem with transportation isn't technology or even existing vehicles, they are social economic problems. Many carbon neutral concepts simply provide too little profit and/or offset existing business models for corporations to pursue.

I am an engineer and I create fluid models. I know from experience that it is impossible to create a model that could accurately predict the fluid dynamics of the entire atmosphere since it is impossible to create an accurate fluid model of a room-sized simulation.

I would not care normally if people want to waste their careers trying to figure out how to create models that can predict complex systems such as the climate, but these people have become politicized by the left, unfortunately, and now the climate change industry has grown to such an extent that the only thing that would keep it from collapse is if there is an actual climate-crisis.

These record contained temperature readings from every part of the world for well over a century at that point. American recording only went back 60 years but it validated the records the British took. Other countries had shorter periods of readings as well that supported them. The result was they discovered there was a 60 year stair step pattern. They called it the temperature oscillation. At that time they could not discover the cause of the pattern, but years later it was discovered that there is a strong correlation between the orbits of Saturn and Jupiter with that cycle. It is not proof, but certainly a possibility. What got them concerned was the regular increase in temperature that was underlying it. Over the years, there have been several other patterns, such as 24, 12 and 8 year cycles. When these cycles are all taken out, you get a straight line graph of .9¬∞C per century. In 30 years, the 60 year cycle will cause a warming of .6¬∞C, then a drop of .05¬∞C in 30 years. The result is that every 60 years since the records were found, the earth has warmed about .55¬∞C. IF you continue that graph into the future from where they were, you get something that is very close to what the actual readings have shown. IF you continue that until the year 2100, it would only have an increase in the temperature of 1.8¬∞C above 1900 temperatures. @Chris Hartley "Yet you fail to provide a reason for it except to wave your arms ar sunspots." This one is going to take time. Sunspots are places of high activity on the sun's surface. Magnetism goes crazy around them and they throw out a lot of material that shoots out of the solar system in what is called the solar wind. When it is particularly high, it can cause disruption in the magnetic field surrounding the earth and cause interference in satellite and other electronic systems. It can seriously mess up power lines. It also blocks out cosmic radiation. This gets its name because it comes from outside our solar system. Every cosmic body, including our sun has its own "fingerprint" of radiation. Some will be high in red for instance, while others are stronger closer to blue. Some of the radiation in the band causes water vapor to form lower than other wise. Our sun is weak in this ban, so most of our clouds form high. Many other start low and climb because the water droplets are smaller. When the solar wind is weak, the cosmic radiation hits the earth a lot more. This causes the clouds to form lower and stay lower as the droplets are bigger. Low level clouds are more reflective of visible light, and more transparent to infrared. The result is that solar energy is reflected while the black body infrared radiation that the earth releases is able to reach space easier. The result is the earth cools. As it cools more winter ice forms and less is melted during the summer causing glaciers to expands. History and proxies both support that this happened during the little ice age. Between the minimums, the ice began to melt, then expand again when the next minimum hit. Since the middle of the 1600's the glaciers have been mostly retreating. There were two more periods were they slightly expanded but not that much. When the solar wind is strong, the cosmic radiation is blocked and the the clouds form higher and smaller drops. The result is that they create high level clouds. These clouds absorb more visible sunlight warming the atmosphere. They are also more reflective of infrared, preventing the black body radiation from escaping as fast. This results in a warming earth. Thus sunspots are the trigger of global warming, even when they fluctuate, because on the average, there is more high level clouds than low. The LONG TERM lack of sunspots triggers a global cooling because of solar wind, cosmic radiation and low level clouds. "The Maunder Minimum, also known as the "prolonged sunspot minimum", is the name used for the period around 1645 to 1715 during which sunspots became exceedingly rare, as was then noted by solar observers." https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Maunder_Minimum There are more about the other minimums if you wish to check them out. "it was realised that increasing them *might* well have an effeect on the atmosphere." MIGHT have an effect. It has never been proven. In fact, it is close to being disproven. The point of matter is how sensitive is the atmosphere to increases in co2. It has been known since the 1800's that co2 emits infrared. Well anticipating what "new" species may appear would be a very difficult task, I don't know if any specialist did try that though. Also although evolution might be sped up by rapid climate change it is a very slow process and humans are also subject to it. In fact humans might have significantly changed as well by the time a significant number of new species will have appeared, all this to say it is not really relevant to ask the question in the sense of evolution.The species we will coexist with will nonetheless not be the same, but this will happen through another process. Species that already exist will become more prominent as others are plummeting in numbers, for example jellyfish are (for now) benefiting from climate change so they become more abundant, but they did not evolve for this they simply are already better fitted to the changes occuring. In the near future we can expect in some oceans to observe greater ratios of jellyfish to other species. Now is this to the benefit or detriment of humans ? In our example it seems that it is a problem as jellyfish are not commonly consumed by humans. But the impact of a greater population of jellyfish on the local environment is more difficult to estimate, it could destroy it as much as it could stabilize it, or have no effect (well I actually don't know if some research was done on this subject). In general in the near future it seems to be more of a nuisance, for example tiger mosquitos (able to transmit a lot of infections between humans) have started to appear in Europe, while bees (highly important to a lot of ecosystems) have been on the decline (well this is not just a consequence of climate change but also of the overuse of pesticides and the removal of nests), and vegetation vanishing will facilitate mud flows from floodings. These are few examples but overall it seems to be very bad. Your second question is much harder to answer, optimists will keep saying you to "believe in our capacity of innovation" but this would be blind faith. A recent study that has been quite widely shared estimates that past 2¬∞C above pre-industrial levels we will enter runaway warming, which means that even if we no longer emit carbon dioxyde, temperature will keep rising to what is estimated as 3 to 4¬∞C above pre-industrial levels. They added that they estimated our chances of being coordinated enough to avoid this to 5%, so without drastic changes in politics we should expect a +3-4¬∞C scenario as most likely (in 2100) and with it the environmental catastrophes that it will bring. Will we survive as a species ? This depends on many other factors than temperature, for example if we keep on poisoning soils, making them infertile without proper fertilizer, we can expect it will be more difficult to keep on feeding everyone. We can already give estimations of how much climate change will cost in terms of damages and human lives, but total human extinction may happen in so many different scenarii that are are all so complex that giving an estimation of the probability of such events would be pure speculations. I hope I have given you some answers, I am sorry that this ended up so long but I really would hate to give you false understanding of something, hence the detours. But I am glad I could be helpfull !

+Joel Sarchet "What does the beginning on an ice-age look like? Are we due for an ice-age?" A formal "Ice Age" is any time when there's a fixed ice sheet on Earth so Earth has been in a formal "Ice Age" for a few millions years and it is right now today. That's just semantics. You mean beginning of a glaciation period (colloquially an "ice age"). This is an excellent question because the answer is interesting as follows. The beginning of a glaciation period looks like the summers at high latitudes of northern hemisphere (65N is used by scientists) become too cool to melt all the snow/ice from the previous winter. This is important because you see the utter "mini ice age" drivel of the coal/oil shill fuckwits during northern hemisphere cold winter spells with a lot of snow. A cold winter or a lot of winter snow cannot ever trigger an "ice age" of any type so long as the following summer is warm enough to melt all the snow/ice. This is obvious. The snow cannot accumulate so there can be no glaciers growing. This is seen on mountain tops that have glaciers. They remain cool enough in summer so the snow/ice doesn't melt. Once summers become cool enough for this then the ice thickens year after year and the pressure at the middle starts pushing the edge south (ice flows). This is exactly what is happening now (and has been a few million years) on Antarctica & Greenland but northern Asia (Russia & other places) and northern North America at latitude 65N don't have cold enough summers for this to happen. The build up takes ~20,000 years or some such once the summers become cold enough, with the process accelerating because ice/snow reflect the Sun "light" a lot.

Well, technically you dont need a second earth, it would be sufficient to know everything about our planet and about every climate factor specifically and how they all come together, so we'd know how changing one factor (i.e. humans) would change the whole. Therein lies the problem: This is actually what we're trying to do. We are getting this interdependency, where to get where we want to get we would already have to know the outcome. This means that since we don't know everything about all the climate factors, everything we do is based on assumptions and this doesn't make for very good science. You are talking about data, yet data only shows us the whole picture (with the human factor). Data can not tell us how we are to interpret it, so any talk of "without humans, the world would look like this" is an educated guess at best. Compare this to quantum physics: First, you start with an observation in the macro spectrum that you don't really understand. You make the assumption it has to do with small particles, so you look for it in the quantum world. Once you find it, you develop a formula that predicts whatever you saw in the first place. This formula is then tested whether a) it can truly predict what you say it can, in every other situation, and b) whether it is compatible with the already established formulas. Now, apply that to climatology: You have the observation, and the assumption and the formula. But the rest is lacking, and this would be the most important part.

That's another topic, but you don't need a second Earth. This is more simple than predicting a century into the future and even more accurate because in this case, you already have all the data you need. For example, 20th century and onward has more data about individual forcings and climate conditions than any other time period. If your model can recreate those climate conditions (modern models are tested that way), then it's probably on the right track. for example https://journals.ametsoc.org/doi/pdf/10.1175/1520-0442%282004%29017%3C3721%3ACONAAF%3E2.0.CO%3B2

Look, what I meant by that, is: If you want to show that gravity exists because things with a big mass exert a force on other stuff, you need to conduct a series of experiments: First you need to show that all things fall to the ground, so you need to prove that every time you let sth go, it will fall. Then, you need to take that same experiment into space to show that because there is nothing that has a strong enough gravitational pull, things won't fall down. So, if you want to show that climate change is anthropogenic, you need to show that climate is changing on our planet (which we have shown), and then you have to show that climate on earth without the human factor would change differently or not at all. And this is the impossible part, since we don't have a second earth where EVERYTHING is the same except for us humans. This is why our simulations will always be vague predictions based on assumptions.

Hey I have a question about the "not eat meat" thing.

So I've got a degree in Environmental Science, and sometimes I feel like I'm streched across 20 different topics. One area I've been trying to understand more of is agriculture.

In my time reading about it, I've came across "Restorative Grazing". I'm probably going to butcher this, but what it claims is that grasslands have been grazed by hoofed animals (ungulates), especially ruminants, for millions of years. Since humans have came along though, we've decimated wild populations of ruminant ungulates- like American bison and Wisents, for example. Now we have cattle and sheep to graze these lands instead.

Now this is important, because grasslands can sequester carbon. This is helped by ungulates- they trample grass so it decomposes into the soil, and their wastes provide nutrients for the grasses to regrow. Some people who research this say that this method could sequester enough carbon to have a HUGE impact on carbon levels.

If you haven't heard of this, and you want a better description, there's a TED talk by Alan Savory- he seems to be the founder of this.

+ Attilio Russo No, livestock does not account for 15% of GHG's. Fermentation, which is how livestock pollute, accounts for roughly half of all METHANE emissions; however, methane accounts for the aforementioned15% of all GHG's, with C02 being the primary GHG. Since they only produce half of the methane, livestock would roughly contribute around 7% of total GHG's, which is less than half of transportation GHG's, which is around 17%. Furthermore, beef cows produce almost all of this methane, with poultry and pigs producing a minuscule amount. Agriculture as a whole, including forestry, accounts for over a quarter of all GHG's. As you said, the primary issue is deforestation, just not meat producing livestock.

This video piece is full of nonsense and alarmist in its predictions. Climate has always changed and there are extremes occurances in weather. This phenomenon is not new. The term "climate change" is the new substitute for "global warming". Although CO2 is conisered a greenhouse gas but water vapour has 40 times the warming potential and there is significantly more water vapour in the atmosphere than carbon dioxide. CO2 is a natural gas and plants need CO2 to grow and live.

Plate tectonics explains the changes in sea levels. Continental shelves are moving with respect to each other. There is movement in the land mass and consequently changes in the measured sea level, which incidently has been rising linearly for the last 100 years.

Computer models are just systems that try to predict future outcomes and these predictions have proved to be false. Weather forecasting is not accurate beyond 5 days or so. So models that try to predict outcomes over hundreds of years is just hokum.

Most of what you are saying is true, however you come to the wrong conclusion: - Indeed water is far more effective at trapping heat on the planet, but has the concentration of water increase in the last 200 years at a very rapid pace? No, however CO2 has. The excess gives rise to new problems, not the natural abundance. - Plate tectonics indeed do explain rise in sea-levels, but only over millions of years. The effect seen in 200 years can thus not be explained by plate tectonics. - There is a big difference between weather models and climate models. Weather is indeed very hard to predict over a long period of time (due to chaos), however climate is interested in the longer term effects such as yearly oscillation swings (due to summer and winter) and seasonal effects. We know these models work well since we used these on data from a long time ago and if we stop them at our current data they give the correct conclusions. This is the first test that is done to check if the model work. After many more tests we can eventually use the model if all tests were successful. That is why computer models are useful. - We can measure the effects of CO2 on the heat-trapping in the laboratory and clearly see these effects. Also even if there were times were the C02 concentration was lower and the temperature higher this still is no argument against the trapping of heat by C02, it just shows that there is more than one factor involved. Now over the last 200 years we have seen little change in all other known factors, however the C02 concentration has doubled. Lastly I would like to emphasize again that it is al about the time intervals. The big problem is not the rise nor the net increase in temperature. It is the fact that this all is happening in a very small time window of +- 200 years.

Take this as an informal counterargument:

Climate change is a chronic problem. It's not the kind of a problem where there's a specific, cutoff point in the near future where "it's too late" to prevent it (if we had to stop all carbon emissions RIGHT NOW, or else London would be underwater in 2020, then you could feasibly say it's too late to save the UK from climate change.)

This means that rather than make one massive push to stop all carbon emissions, we can do two things: first, maintain a general awareness of climate change in the body politic (which is already being done!) and second, to utilize and develop "Keith et al.'s...new technique". If you had told me five years ago that you could pull greenhouse gases out of the atmosphere and not convert swathes of developed land into rainforests, I wouldn't have believed you. But now there's a process -- with a cost analysis per ton -- and now you're saying there's no hope to reverse climate change?

Your video doesn't take into account that for thousands-year long problems comes thousands-year long solutions. Just as we domesticated the Przewalski's horse before we invented the railway, we're starting with a rudimentary machine before developing a cost-effective, high-capacity one. Remember -- we're talking about the 31st century. If people can start to dedicate time, interest and resources now, 1,000 years is plenty of time to increase the number, efficiency, and capacity of these processes as global carbon emissions have peaked and started to decline. Why throw in the towel now?

‚Äã@Lady Flibblesworth It's hilarious reading these comments by sofa scientists who somehow think their "scientific" opinion holds as much merit as a relevant expert with a phD. Funnily enough, you can't just "look it up" and understand it Barry the Baker; it takes years worth of understanding in atmospheric physics and chemistry etc. Who should we believe? The above 85% consenus by climatologists or some dumb fuck who has a Google Degree and worked out CO2 is "plant food". @Crystal Giddens I'm hazarding a guess that you are not a scientist - correct me if I'm wrong. Please have some very basic understanding of CO2 fixation in LIR before even approaching the complexity of climate science. If you don't understand pre-university photosynthesis it really casts doubt on your ability to understand free-radical substitution, ODS mechanisms and radiative forcing etc. If it's 5th grade you should be aware that stomatal closure occurs among plants when exposed to an excess of CO2 to reduce water vapour loss right? ;) No one is denying the sun is responsible for heating. It's simply accepted and considered within this argument; the Melankovitch cycle is already well documented and so have the impacts of sunspots - mathematically we tend to treat solar input as a constant (Gsc) due to the huge amount of data we can access/are currently monitoring. That is why solar forcing may not be seen explicitly accounted for within an abstract; solar variance is marginal and at most Gsc would be minorly manipulated depending upon the circumstances of a specific study. That is why we assess the impact of other variables against the fact we know solar variance is minimal/predominantly constant; the basic assumption being if solar input doesn't change but global temperatures increase there must be other factors responsible. Your tripe about the albedo effect is also fairly irrelevant - by your logic we would already be experiencing a global average of negative radiative forcing due to cloud reflection and our increased global temperatures. However, clouds do not have total global coverage! Even if that was to be the case, not all clouds exact the same strength of albedo effect; the action of albedo by some clouds is miniscule (0) to (for e.g. as with some stratocumulus) up to 0.8. It is also fairly impossible to assume a constant value for average cloud albedo considering we cannot predict the exact composition of cloud type globally to the same degree of accuracy as Gsc for example, especially as many factors (droplet size etc) effect albedo strength. You also seem to fail to understand that additional greenhouse warming has an accessory effect to "natural warming"; no one is claming CO2 is purely responsible for warming, however it's coalesence in the upper troposphere and translation of KE to other gaseous molecules in the troposphere is scientifically accepted, and responsible for tropospheric warming. It also addresses your mistake in being unable to separate the distinction between tropospheric warming and stratospheric cooling. For example KE translation in the stratosphere will result in cooling from the deexcitation of CO2 that has absorbed IR. But the important point is that the most relevant (to heating) CO2 coalesces in the upper troposphere; the same KE translation mechanism doesn't occur - instead emitted radiation is absorbed by closer, and warmer CO2 at a higher pressure and that heat is trapped. This occurs ever more likely at higher tropospheric CO2 quantities, in simple terms in accordance to Kinetic Theory (admittedly, it is more complicated than that). CO2's physical properties exact warming and cooling at different atmospheric levels; a simple fact you should be aware of. Your statement about atmopheric escape in relation to CO2 is also irrelevant. CO2 does not "leave the atmosphere" it is too heavy to undergo Jean's escape, and due to a lot of complicated processes I don't have the time to explain CO2 is typically sequestered. But that does not mean CO2 levels are not a concern as sequestering CAN happen; it's a concern because we are releasing atmopheric CO2 at a much greater rate than is naturally or artificially (carbon capture etc.) sequestered. That is a statistical fact due to the increased concentrations of CO2 recorded. And this is just ONE factor that can impact global flucutation. I'm not even taking into account the different mechanisms for different greenhouse gases and the implications of o-zone depletion or the effects upon weathering patterns and their consequences "Pure science" you will find from the consensus of 12,000 climatology journals from peer-reviewed publishers, and from individuals like Dr. Simon Clarke who possess specialist knowledge of the subject. SmellyPotatoes Mc You people are being simple minded. Yes, co2 is a greenhouse gas. Yes greenhouse gases trap heat. Yes man's emissions add co2 to the atmosphere. No, that is not warming the planet. Let's start with the basics. The SUN warms the planet NOT co2. You must grasp the concept to continue. At night, unless a warm front moves in, it will ALWAYS cool down because the sun is NOT shining. It really is that simple. Since you are being simple minded please keep that in mind as I continue. The sun warms the planet NOT co2. The earth's climate is predominantly homeostatic in that positive and negative feedback loops keep the earth's temperature in balance. I will discuss two of these positive and negative feedback loops below to explain how they help keep the earth's temperature in balance but first know this too. According to NOAA (not my figures, theirs) the earth has warmed 0.7 - 0.9 degrees since coming out of the last glacial period 1901 to present. Considering we were in a glacial period and we are not in one now that is pretty damn stable if you ask me. Right? Less than 1 degree change is stable in anybodies book! *The two positive and negative feedback loops I will discuss are the carbon cycle and albedo.* *The carbon cycle:* The oceans, lakes, rivers streams, etc are by far the largest carbon sinks on earth. Carbon sinks store co2. i.e. they trap co2 from the atmosphere. As it warms (due to the solubility of gases in water) these bodies of water release more of their co2 into the atmosphere aka gasing. notice, the warming comes first, then the gasing occurs. Is it any wonder that it is warmer and there is more co2 in the atmosphere? No! Warming causes gasing. The co2 levels in the atmosphere must always increase as we warm. *Albedo:* Albedo is the property of reflecting sunlight back into space. It is the opposite of a greenhouse gas. It prevents heat from reaching the earth from the sun. Clouds have by far the greatest albedo effect on the earth. They reflect sunlight before it can reach earth and warm it and be trapped by greenhouse gases. Got it? Now, as it waRMS AN INTERESTING NEGATIVE FEEDBACK LOOP KICKS IN. As the earth warms more water evaporates resulting in more moisture in the air. This moister forms clouds. Warming leads to cloud formations. The warmer it is the more clouds there are due to the evaporation of water. As these clouds form more sunlight is blocked and viola! The earth begins to cool. Less sunlight means cooler weather just as night is cooler than day. Another interesting feedback loop kicks in. More clouds and rain means more co2 is washed out of the atmosphere (aka weathering). And since the earth is cooler more of that co2 will remain "trapped" aka stored in the oceans rivers lakes streams ponds etc. Viola! Less co2 means less heat id trapped and cooling continues on and on BUT these feedback loops are so effective it means overall temperature variations over the period in excess of a hundred years is a mere 0.7 to 0.9 degrees even though we are coming out of an ice age! That is freaking stable! You see? The SUN drives the climate NOT co2! There is more but if you cannot grasp this you are hopeless. Man additions of co2 have only served to green the earth. Greening has occurred in the amount of the continental united states in the past 50 years or so. Plants are also co2 store houses that scrub co2 from the atmosphere. You people are being duped! get out of your information ghetto and look at real science. They are LIARS! They want your money and they want control of the earth. This shit is purely political. Not science!

Does nature not do a fantastic job of extracting CO2 from the air in the form of photosynthesising organisms such as plants, including trees, which can lock away carbon for hundreds, or even thousands of years? Can these same trees be used for fuel? That's quite a reinvention of a very old wheel. And what is the immediate cost to the environment of this proposed facility? We're already dealing with mountains of toxic waste created as a by-product of the rush to 'renewable' energy, not to mention a huge increase in the carbon footprint needed to mine materials, move it, processing and so on. If some people took their heads out of their technological backsides we might start getting to grips with problems properly, and realise that not every problem demands a technical solution.

However the question remains, is the tilt increasing or decreasing? If the tilt's decreasing, we'll see more moderate seasons as the centuries and millennia go on. But if it's increasing, the seasons will only become more severe as time goes on. And don't forget that decades ago the climate change crowd was going on about "global cooling" and the prospect of an imminent ice age. Then it went to global warming and "the ice caps will be gone very soon" and now it's climate change. So you'll have to forgive the skepticism regarding the possibility of human involvement because of the politics behind the science. Or rather the proposed solution which revolves around politics.

They are factored in, that why they are used to explain some of the changes that have been happening in climate in history. For example, Milankovitch cycles (the same thing you were talking about) are used to explain the ice age "cycles" Sure other factors, like greenhouse gases and albedo, are counted as well but changes in Earth's position are thought to be the main culprit of these specific changes.

And what about other factors? Earth wobbling axis, for example? We're going nowhere on the CO2 point so let's look for other factors. The earth wobbles on its axis and there are gradual changes in the shape of Earth's orbit from elliptical to circular. The change in tilt happens along a 40k year cycle on average going between 22.1 and 24.5 degrees. Given the current tilt, we appear to be in the middle of that cycle and it even wobbles in the process. As the tilt increases the seasons can get more severe, the question is, is the tilt currently increasing in this cycle or decreasing? And there's the 90k-100k year cycle where the earth's orbit around the sun changes, where are we in that cycle, because that can also affect climate? Sources for the cycles and wobbling axis; https://climate.nasa.gov/news/2428/study-solves-two-mysteries-about-wobbling-earth/ https://earthobservatory.nasa.gov/Features/Milankovitch/milankovitch_2.php

Because CO2 isn't the only thing influencing the climate (the paper makes a point that sun + CO2 has very good correlation) and the "skeptics" misunderstand that nobody is saying it is. Then why are people saying CO2 is the cause of the modern warming period? Because it's the main reason for the time period in question. 1000 years ago, the reason for temperature change was different. A million years ago it was different still.

then why is it NEVER on the same wavelength as temperatures in regards to the constant flux that the two are in? In one era one's high and the other low in the next the reverse is true and they intersect in between. The alarmists only focus on the more recent part of the cycle, say the last few millennia. If you go further back over the millions of years rather than thousands you'll see that one does not correlate with the other at all. If one forced the other then there would be correlation, something that is shown to clearly not be the case. If humanity had any hand in global temperatures at all, it's minuscule at best.

Predicting future scenarios with current technology is, for me, a fundamentally flawed approach which is highly susceptible to being inaccurate. Yes, using the most optimistic values with what we've got now may yield a disappointing result, but this fails to account for the advances in technology that we make during this time. Drawing a disappointing conclusion for the state of affairs 1000 years from now because it 'seems to be impossible' is ignoring how radically different our lives are likely to be in the future; in 50 or 100 years time, let alone 1000. 1000 years ago we may have thought that it wasn't possible that there could exist no God, or that the world was round, or that we would be able to communicate with a huge community of people in all corners of the world in seconds about a moving, talking picture. And yet, here we are. I appreciate the point you're making in the video, but speculating so far ahead is so extremely unlikely to be anything near a reasonable degree of accuracy, and we should simply focus on what we can learn from the past, what we have now, and the near future. Maybe, in a few hundred years, we won't even live on Earth. Maybe we won't even see the end of the century. In 1000 years? A wholly unpredictable, and non-verifiable time scale.

I just want to point out a few things:

As the video points out, the cost of CO2 removal may very well drop, so the premise that global warming is essentially irreversible "on human timescales" is questionable. Air capture will not need to come down in cost by three orders of magnitude, or even two. 1/100 of the estimate in the paper would be really cheap--$30 billion/yr is a really small part of global energy spending, which I think is around $8 trillion/yr.

Nuclear waste decay, and CO2 uptake by geological processes, do not compare well. Nuclear waste has a sharp drop, with a very long, low tail; that's much less true for CO2. IMO it'd be better to not even make the comparison, but find something else.

Also: By the logic in the narration, climate change has always been irreversible, ever since CO2 began to rise. There is no particular point where it became irreversible. The title suggests that climate change has passed some point of no return, beyond which even a cessation of emissions would not stop the process. And there are such claims being made (though I certainly don't agree with them), but if that is the point, it should be made explicitly, and this video never does that.

The technology to replace all electrical generation with solar exists today. All we have to do is put serveral thousand square miles of mirrors, in orbit at a 10,000 miles, to light up solar arrays 24/7 (just reflection, not concentration - no harm to aircraft or birds).

This will require significantly more solar panels than we have today (but only 1/4 what would be required to collect enough energy during day time - and mirrors eliminate the need for storage, which we don't have). The solar arrays have to be in areas with minimal cloud cover.

There is a significant up front cost (but at least an order of magnitude less the $3T for the CO2 removal machine). The annual maintenance would be much lower.

To reduce transportation CO2, use solar to charge electric vehicles. We won't zero out CO2, but reducing it to less than 20% of current gives us a starting point.

As said in the video, we still need remove 50% the existing CO2. That can be done by those machines, or even trees, grown, then stacked up (with a note - in case of ice age, set fire).

Oh dear, not climate models again. According to the 2001 IPCC report, "climate is a coupled, non-linear chaotic system and therefore the long term prediction of future climate states is NOT possible". This is why all climate modeling has been so wildly inaccurate over time. All 107 have been failures to predict future climate conditions. The reason is two-fold. The first thing wrong is that they have not reduced the climate sensitivity on the GCMs, adhering to AGW orthodoxy. We now know that sensitivity might be less than 25% of what was once believed.

The second problem is even more difficult. They simply haven't enough actual measured data to simulate such a huge dynamic system as our planet. More than 90% of the temperature readings over land are artificial, rather than measured data. Over the oceans (72% of the earth's surface) the amount of real data is infinitesimal. All the rest of the input for the models is interpolated material ... not real data. Science relies on data ... real, factual observations, not estimates of estimates of extrapolations.

In other words Susan Solomon's models are rubbish because they use even less actual data than the Global Circulation Models which operate so poorly at present. Her models run faster because they rely on even less information. These new "models" are nothing short of fear mongering ... but Solomon, et al will never have to account for their failure because it's projected centuries beyond their life span. But if we believe and act on such poorly conceived "science" the cost to us, here and now will be devastating. Carbon capture is not only wildly expensive, it's among the most idiotic "solutions" to a non existent problem there is.

Great video, but unfortunately you committed one massively glaring and comically ironic logic fail while making your argument that "climate change is already irreversible" (impossible to reverse). According to you, the inspiration for this video was an article describing a newly invented method for removing carbon from the atmosphere and converting it into energy-dense fuel, which you then implied was a futile invention, due to your belief that "climate change is already irreversible."

Then, you go on to quote a report's 1000-year projections for atmospheric carbon density in an "even if we were to stop emitting carbon today" scenario, BUT you fail to consider or include a hypothetical projection for an "if we started REMOVING carbon from the atmosphere" scenario.

I wonder if it would possible in the future and as a possible solution to the power grid's duck curve;

To use home solar energy to produce fuel for your car.

In case you don't know, the duck curve is becoming a problem for power companies as more solar gets installed in homes. In power engineering there is typical "power flow" and as you expect the power flows from generators to homes. Now the power flow is reversing, where homes are becoming generators, and this is a problem. This will cause power companies nearly shut down their generators to prevent over generation in mid day when solar output is maximum.

Lines may become overloaded because distrubution lines were designed to go from a power source to a power consumer; not power source to power source to consumer like the internet would act. Like line voltages are rated based on the amount of customers its designed to feed. Power=IV and the I (current) is what makes the line hot. So power companies up the voltage to deliver the same power (the trade off is that the line is more dangerous and requires more isolation at high voltage). The further away you get from generation the voltage level goes down as there should be less load. But if you're a generator, then you'll increase load on the line which was not designed to take that load.

If your solar panels are producing fuel, then your solar installation is not injecting power into the line. And the power generation will become more efficient as the power company doesnt have to rapidly turn on and off the generators over the day.

A good question! We often talk about CO2 absorbing light, so you might expect that by removing CO2 the sun will become brighter in the sky. However substances don't absorb all light equally, and CO2 specifically absorbs infra-red wavelengths. So this is light which lies outside our visible spectrum, meaning you can't see it with your eyes. If you *could* see infra-red though, the sun wouldn't look brighter if we removed a bunch of CO2 from the atmosphere, as the sun's light is actually mostly in the visible and ultraviolet parts of the spectrum (so light we can see and stuff which has wavelengths shorter than blue light). Instead, the Earth would look brighter, as the Earth emits light in the infra-red (which, remember, we can't see). So to answer your question, no the sun wouldn't look brighter in the sky if we removed a load of CO2 because it absorbs wavelengths of light which we can't see, and which the sun doesn't emit. I hope that helped!
Not to mention that the carbon extracted from the air would have to be NOT burned, i.e. we can't use it as fuel for this to work. We'd have to pump it back into the ground. It just won't happen.

Good video, but with one flaw/omission in the economic analysis: a ton of CO2 can be converted into roughly 100 gallons of gasoline, which at the current price of $3/gal would pay for the CO2 capture process quite easily.

Of course, each of those gallons will also require about 33 kwh of energy for the conversion process, which would add another dollar or two to the price of gas, depending on what sources were used and how they were financed. But there are some new solar PV installations today delivering power at $0.03/kwh, so if the cost of CO2 capture can be done economically at $100/ton, then yes, it is not hard at all to make a business case for doing this today for a profit.

Of course, even that won't solve the problem, it will only slow down the train wreck. However, in combination with other strategies like permaculture, electrification of transportation, and renewable energy, there may yet be some hope of making significant CO2 reductions by the end of the century.

https://www.epa.gov/ghgemissions/overview-greenhouse-gases

NOX and Methane are ~15% of GHG combined. Of those, animal agriculture is about 5% and 35% respectively. Growing crops contributes about 75% of the NOX emissions, with all vehicular transport being 5%. Coal mining is about 8% of Methane, and natural gas and petroleum systems account for 31%.

81% of GHG is CO2, and ~75% of that is electricity, transport and industry.

I think it's pretty clear where we should be concentrating. 75% of 81% is a way bigger problem than 75% of 6%. Exchanging fossil fuels for renewables will not only eliminate that 75% of CO2, but also the 39% of Methane from coal and gas/petroleum, and ~10% of the NOX from transport and stationary combustion (assuming the latter is generally power generation).

So in both cases, energy and transport VASTLY outweigh the emissions from the animal agriculture sector. What I didn't realise is how bad the NOX emissions are from agriculture generally, and this is legitimately something that we could do better, but it definitely does not help to stop eating meat.

Having said that, I think we should all eat less meat, and better quality produced with better standards. I pay a premium (20-30% I guess) at a butcher that sources responsibly, they can tell me where all the meat comes from and I can check on those producers. As a bonus, it's FRICKIN' DELICIOUS!! I will never go back to supermarket meat, I just eat a little less than I used to.

Andy Lee Robinson Hi Andy, I've had a look through the material you provided and have a couple of things I'd like to point out to you. I'll deal with each link in a separate post. With regard to the surface radiative forcing of CO2 experiments: Firstly, the experiment determined that CO2 forcing is only 68% of what was expected from AGW climate models. Using the IPCC formula one calculates that the radiative forcing of CO2, based on the measured increase in CO2 concentration, should have been 0.29W/m2. Instead it was measured as 0.2W/m2. So that's the first problem. Secondly the experiment found that CO2 forcing accounts for only 10% of radiative forcing. Is it possible that water vapour is responsible for most DLWR and not CO2? At the very least, this experiment confirms what many have accepted long ago, that CO2 is responsible for only a tenth of DLWR radiation. The experiment does show an increase in DLWR forcing however, so let's explore a possible cause. As you will note, the experiment period started during a la Nina cycle and ended during an el Nino cycle. This accounted for a half a degree increase in tropospheric temperatures during the experiment period. Since warmer air results in more DLWR, could the increase in tropospheric temperature have caused the increase in DLWR? "But the greenhouse feedback mechanism will eventually result in more water vapour which will cause a further increase in DLWR!" I hear you protest. Well let's go to the temperature records to find out. It might interest you to note that in Alaska during the 2000 to 2010 there was no increase in surface temperatures. And in fact during the 2010 to 2011 period immediately following the experiment, mean temperatures in Alaska fell by around 4 degrees, resulting in the coldest temperature recorded in 94 years. So in fact it looks like this experiment proves that the greenhouse feedback mechanism is a thing of fantasy.

You have the shoe on the wrong foot, Jake K. The burden of proof lies with those who believe that CO2 does rise the Earth's temperature more than a tiny fraction of the total amount. So far that has not happened. If you want to know why that is, read Richard Lindzen or Judith Curry. The issue is a thing called climate sensitivity. No one with any knowledge of the subject is saying that CO2 hasn't some effect in warming the planet, but that effect is very small and occurs most powerfully with the 1st 100 or so parts per million. From there on its ability to trap long wave radiation diminishes logarithmically. This is well known. Also, below around 150 ppm there is too little CO2 to support plant growth. Before CO2 started to rise, at around 270 ppm it was dangerously low to support abundant plant growth. Now, at ~400 ppm the plants are much happier.

Holy shit a reply from the man himself!! If there are both positive and negative feedback loops - that only means they would either cancel each other out, or they average out into one positive feedback loop, or a negative one. If it's positive or negative, the Earth would've been screwed from the get go regardless of humans. Therefore, when there's no human input, the Earth's CO2 levels must be _self correcting_ , i.e. when CO2 levels are too high, the negative feedback loops have more punch, and when CO2 is too low, the positive feedback loops win over. Only this scenario would create an equilibrium allowing CO2 levels to remain stable over time, any other scenario would have CO2 levels spiral exponentially to either 0 or infinity due to effects of chaos. And if that's the case, then while an additional human input of CO2 will produce a temporary rise in temperature, eventually we will again find a natural equilibrium, because although we've increased the CO2 levels, because we've done that, the net negative feedback loops will become more pronounced, while the net positive feedback loops will diminish, and (as long as human CO2 input is constant), they'll be a point where the loops once again reach equilibrium. I can make an analogy with air resistance vs gravity. As you know, falling objects have air resistance, and the faster the velocity, the more air resistance. Therefore this is an example of a negative feedback loop, because if a falling object momentarily goes faster than the terminal velocity where air resistance and gravity are in equilibrium, then the object slows back down to terminal velocity. Likewise, if the object momentarily goes slower than the terminal velocity, gravity win over the air resistance, creating a positive feedback loop, and making the object speed back to terminal velocity. Any other universe where the object didn't have a positive feedback loop when going to slow AND a negative feedback loop when going to fast, would inevitably result in the object either coming to a complete stop or speeding up indefinitely. Now in this analogy, human input of CO2 is equivalent to reducing the object's surface area. By doing so, you'll have decreased the force of air resistance, making the object fall faster/have a higher terminal velocity. But the same positive/negative feedback loops apply, so although the object will temporarily fall faster, it will inevitably reach a new terminal velocity again, where the feedback loops cancel out and it's all ok. Is this correct?

Because it's not that simple - there are both positive and negative feedback loops. For example more CO2 -> warmer, wetter planet -> more photosynthesis from plants -> less CO2. But then at the same time more CO2 -> warmer, wetter planet -> more water vapour absorbing thermal wavelengths of radiation -> warmer planet. There are feedback loops all over the place, hence the need for complicated models!

Colder summers melt the snow more slowly and that allows the snow cover to build up. As the snow builds, the ground grows lighter in color which reflects more sunlight which helps the Earth get a little cooler. Over time and if enough ice builds, the oceans start to cool as well from the colder air and as the oceans cool, CO2 is absorbed and the Earth cools even more and if this continues, you have an ice age - until the Earth's orbit returns and Northern Hemisphere summers start to warm up and the entire process reverses.
