There is no such thing as a normal CO2 level. Over the last 500 million years, CO2 in the atmosphere has, on average, been in decline. But if you look a bit closer, the effects and differences at different times were dramatic. If you take the earliest times, the CO2 at that time was indeed very high. But the sun played a huge role in why it was not as hot: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Solar_luminosity During that time, solar luminosity was several percent lower than today. That may not sound a lot, but the usual solar cycles we see today are on the order of one-tenth of a percent change in luminosity and that already shows a well observable effect. Later on during the Eocene was one of the hottest periods of the last 500 million years. It peaked during the PETM, with a synchronous peak in CO2. After that, CO2 and Temperature both declined, until the ice caps started forming at the end of the Eocene. Meanwhile, the sun is still increasing in intensity, which already hints that it can not be the cause of the long term cooling, but that instead greenhouse gases being the cause is much more likely.

The cloud theory was brought up and tested at CERN, in the CLOUD experiment using a particle accelerator and a Gas Chamber to simulate different parts of the atmosphere. You can find a paper on the results here: http://science.sciencemag.org/content/early/2016/10/26/science.aaf2649 I'll quote the relevant part here: "We tested the effect of changes in the GCR ionization rate that occur between solar maximum and minimum (supplementary materials, section 13; Ref. (17)). Over the solar cycle, the global mean change in CCN at cloud base altitude (915 hPa, usually around 850 m above the surface) is only 0.1% (Fig. 4B) with local changes of no more than 1%. This is expected from the experimentally derived sub-linear dependence of the inorganic nucleation rate on ionization rate (supplementary materials, section 8) and consistent with previous assessments (49, 50)." GCR = galactic cosmic rays, CCN = cloud condensation nuclei. Or in other words, neglible.

We are currently in an ice age called the Quaternary glaciation. Ice ages last millions of years, while interglacial periods within them only last around 15,000. During normal times, Earth averages about 2,000 ppm of co2 without any problems, in fact, life seems to thrive in these conditions. The radiative transfer models such as MODTRAN by the US Airforce show that the no-feedback warming caused by a doubling of CO2 (for example from pre-industrial 280 ppm to 560 ppm) causes about 1¬∞C of warming. If you assume that the relative instead of the absolute humidity of the air stays constant during the increase of temperature, that increases further. All the other feedbacks due to albedo changes from for example retreating ice, changes in cloud coverage etc. are not at play in that estimation, so it is most likely a lower limit for an estimate of the climate sensitivity of CO2. When determining the total energy budget of incoming, reflected and outgoing radiation, CO2 contributes about roughly 25% to total greenhouse warming: http://www.geo.utexas.edu/courses/387H/PAPERS/kiehl.pdf

You say "lets be super optimistic" and assume CO2 emissions remain constant. Until the year 3000? That's an incredibly pessimistic assumption. Either solar or nuclear power (with nuclear taken to include fusion) is likely to displace fossil fuels within the next century or so. This agrees with the sources used in you video, which show CO2 emissions peaking this century, and the whole idea of CO2 removal presupposes an abundant supply of clean energy. So we are not talking about constantly having to offset billions of tonnes of emissions every year; we are talking about having around 900 years (if the year 3000 is you deadline) to clean up a few centuries worth of carbon, the bulk of which probably comes just from the period of about 1950 to 2050.
Also the world economy is likely to be considerably larger in the 22nd through 30th centuries as productivity rises and countries that were left behind by the industrial revolution rapidly catch back up with the West; if we assume a population of 10 billion people with the same per capita income as the present day US, that gives a gross world product of nearly $600 trillion per year, about 6 times the current amount.
And as you mention, the cost of removing carbon could well be reduced further in the future.
In your video you calculate a cost equivalent to about 3% of GWP, and while it may be difficult and arguably not worth it, it's not, in fact, "simply not possible" to give up 3% of your income. With the above points taken into account, the cost is more likely to be well under 1%.

Matthew Jenkinson Batteries run everything in a Solar System, the solar panels only recharge the batteries, you clearly do not know how Solar Systems work. I have eight 100 amp hour batteries. The batteries run our lights and charge our cell phones, tablets and laptops. The solar panels run nothing. They only recharge the batteries. Anyone who has studied solar systems and installs them, knows this. I have a 3,500 watt inverter. It will surge to 5,000 watts. This means i need minimum 5 deep cycle batteries, or I may fry my inverter. So, I have 8 batteries. The 8 batteries allow up to 8,000 watts of draw. If I had 8 X 100 Watt Solar Panels (*,000 Watts or 8KW) and 2 batteries, I would fry my system. It would be constantly going down and my two batteries would not even last a couple months. The solar panels are Solar Chargers. The Charge Controller limits how much the panels will charge, so I do not over charge my batteries. I have a 12 volt DC system. The solar panels put out 18 volts sometimes. The charge controller steps it down to a 13.2-14.5 volt current. The charge controller take the solar panels energy and uses it to charge the batteries, or to keep them charged. We do not run the fans 24 hours a day. We do not run the laptops, tablets or net books 24 hours a day. Only our cell phones are on all day. Well sometimes we charge them in the car going down the road, or charge them at work, so even they are not on the solar bank all the time. The batteries only need to be recharged the amount that is taken. It I run the 1,200 watt microwave for 2 minutes to heat a hot dog and chili, the solar will replace that long before the sun goes down. It is about knowing how to calculate your uses and having more than enough batteries to do it. Then the proper solar array to replace what you use on average. We also have a 1,600/2,000 watt generator and a 3,500/5,000 watt generator. We rarely use them. Yes, I have a battery charge running of my house power, but it is a variable charger that does 1.5 amps to keep the bank topped off, or up to 8 amps to ramp up the charging, but when it is topped out at 8 amps, it is only drawing about 200 watts. I only use it when I need to, which may be once a month for a day or so. Keep in mind that most of the time it is not even running at 8 amps. It supplements the solar panels if needed. The batteries run things. The Solar charges the batteries. My battery cables, the copper wire is about as thick as an adult mans thumb. The solar panels wires are tiny as a #2 pencil lead. Not a #2 pencil, but the lead inside the pencil. How is that going to run a microwave oven, toaster, waffle iron, hair dryer, 40 inch TV or most of the other things inside a home? Size the Battery Bank first, then the solar panels next and then the appropriate charge controller. We use cables one size heavier than needed, so we never stress the system. It is always best to use thicker wires than needed. Have multiple inverters. Do not use a 3,500 watt inverter to run a 24 inch TV. Use a 450 watt or 700 watt inverter. Our inverters 3,500 watt 2,000 watt 750 watt 450 watt 250 watt 125 watt Some things that are AC power, people run on DC power and do not even use an inverter. The reason is that if it uses 120 volts AC and it has no computer type technology inside it, like a basic toaster, toaster oven, hair dryer, drill, skill saw and such. It only wants the 120 volts. People will series their batteries and 10 batteries that are 12 volt in series will give 120 volts. You can see people run these things on DC, from their battery bank. Usually only in emergency situations, but it can be done. Kid; "Now I know." G.I. Joe: "And knowing is half the battle."

SushiFairy in some places you can buy a 100 watt solar panel for $100 dollars. That is way cheaper than it used to be. You should know that every home is not the same. After replacing our bulbs with LED bulbs, changing to gas cooking and low amp refrigerators, switching from four 1,500 watt desktop computers to 120 watt laptops, canning so we do not need large refrigerators and freezer, using out cell phones, tablets and netbooks, instead of our laptops, getting a 40 inch 120 watt TV and a 24 inch 12 volt DC TV, a couple portable DVD players that run on 12 volts DC, using the Air Conditioner only when we need it and a few other things. Our Utilities bill went from $600 a month to about $120 a month. That $480 a month is almost $5,000 a year. We live in Florida so we get a lot of sun. We also have an electric water heater and a gas water heater. It cost to do all these things, but we save almost $500 a month. That is over $5,000 a year. Yes, we have 95 watts in solar panels. They are 15 watt panels and we have six of them. When the last hurricane hit Florida, the city power was out for weeks. We still had lights, internet, fans, charging for our tables, cell phones and net books. We gave up out four 1,500 watt desktop gaming computers for gaming laptops that use 120 watts each. More batteries are important, because the solar panes do not run anything. The batteries run everything, but the solar panels only charge the batteries. Less panels just means longer charging times.

Burgess, in Global Safety of Fresh Produce, 2014 10.3.1 Carbon Soil carbon, which correlates with the soil organic matter levels, was measured in 1981 and 2002. In 1981, the soil carbon levels were about the same (about 2%) in both the organic and conventional systems (Pimentel et al., 2005). In 2002, however, the soil organic matter in the organic systems was about 5%, whereas in the conventional system, it remained about 2%. The higher soil organic matter levels found in the organic systems cause the soil to retain more water that results in better crop yields during droughts, reduces soil erosion, increases plant nutrient retention and increases biological diversity. There was about 4000 kg per ha of soil carbon in the conventional system but about 10 000 kg per ha of soil carbon in the organic system in 2002. The higher water content accounted for the higher corn and soybean yields during the drought years faced by these systems (Lotter et al., 2003). Higher soil organic matter levels cause greater soil nitrogen retention, greater microbial biodiversity, and promote the presence and growth of arbuscular mycorrhizal fungi that penetrate the roots of crops and facilitate the movement of plant nutrients from the soil into the crop plants resulting in better crop growth and yields (Pimentel et al., 2005). Higher soil carbon levels also hold soil particles together so less soil erosion occurs (Pimentel et al., 2005). Thanks for the update By reading your previous statements (against me, and probably against a skeptic), I thought you were totally unaware of the MSR options. I agree, it's a hard sell! I did some math and I think there is enough deserts in the world to grow all that extra soil. You see, _trees_ are not really the solution, but the soil beneath can be. SOC or soil organic carbon is much higher in some soils than in others. Now, what probably set you off is that I said something about the Sahara, and yes, that's a no no (because of political and religious problems)' However, here's my "math" that I just figured out a few days ago (hence my excitement, last night). We need to get the 410 ppm CO2 back down to about 300 ppm. How do we do that? First, how much is that? The atmosphere currently has about 0.041% by volume CO2, (equal to 410 ppm) which corresponds to approximately 3200 gigatons of CO2. Simple math tells us we have to safely sequester 850 gigatons of the CO2 from the air. How do we put all that into the soil? First, how much land is required? SOC or soil organic carbon is only 0.5% in desert soils. But is usually about 2.5% in rather good soil. CO2 weighs more than just the carbon component. The carbon content of CO2 is 12/44. The "44" is one carbon at molecular weight of 12 and two oxygen at 2 x 16. Therefore, we can divide the 850 GT of CO2 by the inverse, 3.666 to get a total of 230 GT of actual carbon that needs to be put back into the ground. This is what photosynthesis is for! There's only about 36,000 tons of carbon per sq km at 2.5% SOC, possible to be sequestered. Perhaps much more. 230,000,000,000 tons of excess carbon divided by 36,000 equals almost 6.4 million sq km of desert needed to be irrigated. That's almost 2.47 million sq miles or fully FIFTEEN Californias! However, it's less than the Sahara's 3.55 million sq miles. Now that we know that it's possible to sequester the excess CO2 into the desert ground, we need to find out how much water will be required. I believe, that's the hard part! Too much nuclear, or way too much solar? We'd probably need 10x our present global energy demands just to build everything, desalinate such vast quantities of water, and supply the usual power demands for more developing nations, a greatly expanded space presence, too. All the while reducing FFs via the electrification of "everything".

I should mention I received a reply from Simon Clark himself on another comment thread here. Since he's the go to man, figured I should repost his reply and mine for honesty's sake. Simon Clark Because it's not that simple - there are both positive and negative feedback loops. For example more CO2 -> warmer, wetter planet -> more photosynthesis from plants -> less CO2. But then at the same time more CO2 -> warmer, wetter planet -> more water vapour absorbing thermal wavelengths of radiation -> warmer planet. There are feedback loops all over the place, hence the need for complicated models! Zacharie Etienne Holy shit a reply from the man himself!! If there are both positive and negative feedback loops - that only means they would either cancel each other out, or they average out into one positive feedback loop, or a negative one. If it's positive or negative, the Earth would've been screwed from the get go regardless of humans. Therefore, when there's no human input, the Earth's CO2 levels must be self correcting , i.e. when CO2 levels are too high, the negative feedback loops have more punch, and when CO2 is too low, the positive feedback loops win over. Only this scenario would create an equilibrium allowing CO2 levels to remain stable over time, any other scenario would have CO2 levels spiral exponentially to either 0 or infinity due to effects of chaos. And if that's the case, then while an additional human input of CO2 will produce a temporary rise in temperature, eventually we will again find a natural equilibrium, because although we've increased the CO2 levels, because we've done that, the net negative feedback loops will become more pronounced, while the net positive feedback loops will diminish, and (as long as human CO2 input is constant), they'll be a point where the loops once again reach equilibrium. I can make an analogy with air resistance vs gravity. As you know, falling objects have air resistance, and the faster the velocity, the more air resistance. Therefore this is an example of a negative feedback loop, because if a falling object momentarily goes faster than the terminal velocity where air resistance and gravity are in equilibrium, then the object slows back down to terminal velocity. Likewise, if the object momentarily goes slower than the terminal velocity, gravity win over the air resistance, creating a positive feedback loop, and making the object speed back to terminal velocity. Any other universe where the object didn't have a positive feedback loop when going to slow AND a negative feedback loop when going to fast, would inevitably result in the object either coming to a complete stop or speeding up indefinitely. Now in this analogy, human input of CO2 is equivalent to reducing the object's surface area. By doing so, you'll have decreased the force of air resistance, making the object fall faster/have a higher terminal velocity. But the same positive/negative feedback loops apply, so although the object will temporarily fall faster, it will inevitably reach a new terminal velocity again, where the feedback loops cancel out and it's all ok.

About public transport; it depends. If you talk about buses and diesel trains, they pollute as much as a car per passenger. Further they generate more tax revenues that are used to pollute even more. There is a reason why public transport is 20 times as expensive per distance unit than driving in your car. Un-piloted autonomous electric trains are the only mass transport that pollutes less than driving in your own car, but building them creates massive CO2 deficits, that takes decades to catch up with. Cycling, even better on an E-bike is the least polluting means of transport, but that is only if you are a vegetarian. The little ice age started before the Maunder minimum and was NOT a global event (which changes in solar dynamics are) thereby proving that the little ice age was not 'caused by' the lower sunspot activity of the Maunder minimum. The Dalton minimum is more indicative of a correlation but the relationship is not well understood. It is certainly not causal. The term double peak is not confusing at all, the way you are trying to use it is. The models actually work very well despite not including this solar variation (which further suggests it is not the cause of the current warming). The question I was asking you is: If the warming is being caused mostly by solar cycles, why can't you (or some other amateur climatologists) develop a model based on this solar activity that replicates the temperature data we have available? Anthropogenic global warming is not fake, it is exaggerated for political purposes. Most of the warming that has taken place is from solar activity, namely the Modern Maximum that started around the industrial revolution. In addition, Earth is dipping back down into the next glacial maximum of this ice age where co2 levels will drop by as much as 250 ppm naturally for 100,000+ years. Finally, 400 ppm is nowhere near enough to cause runaway greenhouse effect. For most of Earths history, co2 levels have been around 2,000 ppm. Earth is at all time low co2 levels. Most vegetation is suffering because of it. If it drops below 150 ppm, all photosynthetic organisms will go extinct and virtually everything else with them. We are at a much greater risk of freezing than we are of burning, not that you need to worry about either of those things anyway.

At present we're all living in the Goldilocks period of the Holocene Inter-glacial which usually last around the time span ours has lasted already, around 15,000 years.THEN IT GETS COLD AGAIN ... real cold. Long before the pitifully tiny warming effect due to CO2 can become dangerous ... we'll be well in to the next cold phase of the present ice age. Our present warm period needs many degrees more than the present to win back the heat that was lost during The Little Ice Age.

My reply to another thread above: https://www.epa.gov/ghgemissions/overview-greenhouse-gases NOX and Methane are ~15% of GHG combined. Of those, animal agriculture is about 5% and 35% respectively. Growing crops contributes about 75% of the NOX emissions, with all vehicular transport being 5%. Coal mining is about 8% of Methane, and natural gas and petroleum systems account for 31%. 81% of GHG is CO2, and ~75% of that is electricity, transport and industry. I think it's pretty clear where we should be concentrating. 75% of 81% is a way bigger problem than 75% of 6%. Exchanging fossil fuels for renewables will not only eliminate that 75% of CO2, but also the 39% of Methane from coal and gas/petroleum. So in both cases, energy and transport VASTLY outweigh the emissions from the animal agriculture sector. What I didn't realise is how bad the NOX emissions are from plant agriculture, and this is legitimately something that we could do better, but it definitely does not help to stop eating meat. Having said that, I think we should all eat less meat, and better quality produced with better standards. I pay a premium (20-30% I guess) at a butcher that sources responsibly, they can tell me where all the meat comes from and I can check on those producers. As a bonus, it's FRICKIN' DELICIOUS!! I will never go back to supermarket meat, I just eat a little less than I used to.

chem - You're apparently unaware of how Earth's ecosystem is extremely interconnected. There's an absurd number of factors that keep the entire food chain in existence. Obviously there are species that would outlive us, but an Earth that is so badly damaged as to be inhospitable for humans would likely be on such a severe decline that the extinction of all other species would inevitably follow, whether it be hundred or thousands of years later. It would not just "bounce back" as if nothing happened after we've completely ruined the atmosphere, which by the way is the only thing keeping us from looking like every other dead planet. In simpler terms: Any man-made changes that are drastic enough to cause our extinction will probably extinct most if not all other species in time. You should study mini ecosystems and how they work. Basically, you mess up one component and you fu*k the whole thing up. Pretty simple concept. That's where we're at right now. We're messing up the atmosphere, which is THE main component that you can't just slap a band-aid on or do without. You can't just assume it will start fixing itself because we're gone, it will just continue on the same detrimental path that led humans to extinction, which eventually would extinct everything else. Make sense?

Great essay! It's the most accessible introduction to the irreversibility argument that I've seen so far. I suspect there would be less overall scepticism towards climate change in general if there was more in-depth information that explains the actual mechanisms that drive it, instead of poorly thought-out metaphors and general nonsense in the way it's presented to the public. However, I fundamentally disagree with the attitude of technological pessimism that you express at the end of your video. The reality scientists, activists and politicians prefer to ignore is that if industrializing--as well as recently industrialized--nations were to make the switch to renewable energy right now, they would lose their competitive advantage more or less instantly. It's easy for us, living in the developed word, to pontificate about reductions in emmission: we can afford it. If the LCOE of the various sources of renewable energy do not come down, I suspect we will be looking at another half century or so until we reach peak emmissions. There's a reason why China funds so much research into solar power.

https://www.epa.gov/ghgemissions/overview-greenhouse-gases NOX and Methane are ~15% of GHG combined. Of those, animal agriculture is about 5% and 35% respectively. Growing crops contributes about 75% of the NOX emissions, with all vehicular transport being 5%. Coal mining is about 8% of Methane, and natural gas and petroleum systems account for 31%. 81% of GHG is CO2, and ~75% of that is electricity, transport and industry. I think it's pretty clear where we should be concentrating. 75% of 81% is a way bigger problem than 75% of 6%. Exchanging fossil fuels for renewables will not only eliminate that 75% of CO2, but also the 39% of Methane from coal and gas/petroleum. So in both cases, energy and transport VASTLY outweigh the emissions from the animal agriculture sector. What I didn't realise is how bad the NOX emissions are from plant agriculture, and this is legitimately something that we could do better, but it definitely does not help to stop eating meat. Having said that, I think we should all eat *less* meat, and better quality produced with better standards. I pay a premium (20-30% I guess) at a butcher that sources responsibly, they can tell me where all the meat comes from and I can check on those producers. As a bonus, it's FRICKIN' DELICIOUS!! I will never go back to supermarket meat, I just eat a little less than I used to.

A common fallacy. People need to realise that our society (regardless of widespread dietary proclivities...) will continue to cause global warming. To change from a carnivorous to herbiferous diet will still require mass industrialisation. Thus, will still generate heat as well as GHG emissions. . The underlying cause being simply TOO MANY PEOPLE. We are heading towards population overshoot. . And *no,* livestock agrigulture, though a serious contributor to atmospheric GHG emissions, is not the largest contributor. That forcing belongs to industrial civilisation and a large chunk of that is the military industrial complex. . The point is so often missed, though Simon did mention it... Global warming is *LOCKED IN* for the forseeable future. So even if, all humans ceased producing CO2 (et al) and turned vegan this evening, it would not make one jot of difference to global warming. This is due to the latent effect of GHG molecules in the atmosphere. . Also, one particular GHG - Methane (CH4), which is yet another sequestered carbon deposit (a fossil fuel...), has been kept sequestered by a relatively stable climatic period (the 18 odd thousand years up to the industrial revoloution...). . CH4 can only be stored under extreme pressure and at sub zero temperatures. Here the CH4 molecules are locked within 'cages' of frozen H2O molecules - ice. These cages are called 'clathrates' or 'hydrates'. They exist naturally all over the planet. Locked up in the sediments of the planet's oceans. Where they remain sequestered by the extreme pressures and sub-zero temperatures that are prevalent at extreme depths of all the major oceans. . However, CH4 clathrates also exist in large quantities in the more shallow regions of our oceans, essentially the continental shelves surrounding each continent. Any release of CH4 from deep clathrate deposits, would not reach the atmosphere in large quantites, due to absorption/assimilation of CH4 in the ocean water column. Whereas clathrates thawing in shallow regions, have less of a water column (a difference, on average of around 14 thousand feet....). Thus more CH4 can and *is* reaching the atmosphere. . Currently, the East Siberian Sea, continental shelf, the region of the Arctic ocean that is directly north of eastern Russia (Siberia) is outgassing methane. This is increasing and is directely related to a warming Arctic ocean. CH4 is also outgassing from the Canadian shelf and of course all across the northern tundra regions (Canada, Scandinavia and Siberia). Here the clathrates that were hitherto locked up in deep permafrost, which of course is now thawing, as part of the retreating cryosphere (the planet's 'icy' regions - Ice Sheets - Greenland, East and West Antarctica - Sub tropical glaciers - Alaska, The Rockies, The Andes, The Alps, The Himalayas, Kamchatkan peninsular and the odd high mountains elsewhere - Sea Ice - Arctic and Antarctica - Permafrost regions - Tundra), all in retreat, due to global warming. . The release of CH4 is of extreme concern and is one of countless ' positive feedback loops' triggered by GW. . CH4 - molecule for molecule is around 100 times more potent as a greehouse gas (GHG) than that of CO2. The concern is that it is estimated that around 500 GIGAtons of CH4 exist in the ESS (East Siberian Shelf) alone... That with the continual increase in Arctice oceanic temperatures, a large outgassing may occur. This is coloquially termed - a 'Clathrate Burp/bomb/gun' event. Such an event, will accelerate the ongoing GW. . None of this was mentioned in this video because CO2 emissions still remain the primary driver for global warming. Also there is a MSM clampdown on information regarding the Arctic CH4 emissions.... But the research is not new and is readily available to anyone who wishes to dig further. . The point is, that global warming is locked in. There is no feasible technology that can mitigate this process. Nor will any personal endeavour make one jot of difference. We started the snowball... Now it is out of control. . Running in paralell to global warming/climate change is the ongoing Sixth Mass Extinction. This too, was triggered by the rise of human civilisation. Given that humans would not readilly agree to curb population, nor reduce or abolish industry - a return to medieval living - Both the MEE VI and global warming will continue apace. . The upshot is - the EXTINCTION of all major species on this planet, which includes all vertebrates and by physical definition - homo sapiens-sapiens. . I have only mentioned TWO vectors here - Global warming due to GHG emissions (CO2/CH4/NO2/H2O) and sequestered carbon release (CH4). The reality is far worse - for there are those countless self-reinforcing feedback loops, as well as other anthropogenic vectors - Radionuclides (nuclear power and weapons...), which is the ionising radiation emtted by the nuclear process and extremely lethal to life... Toxins - plastics, chemicals, pesticides, mineral processing etc... And the ongoing destructive processes - deforestation, mass habitat loss mining and drilling, fracking, dam building, urban growth, the depletion of the planets FINITE resources and of course - fisheries and (MONO)AGRICULTURE... . Not to mention the planet's own natural processes of tectonics, volcanism, ocean circulation etc... In fact the latter is being seriously affected by global warming as the oceans are the primary absorber of CO2, which in turn increases the mass of the oceans and decreases the pH levels - hence that oceans are turning acidic, with subsequent habitat loss and species extinction. The increase in mass, of the oceans, together with the thawing of all land-borne ice - deglaciation - causing higher global sea levels, again resulting in habitat loss and species extinction. . Also Oxygen levels (atmospheric and marine) have decreased over *recent* decades. Anoxic conditions (depleted O2) are not conducive to the continual survival of O2 breathing/processing organisms... . All this is accelerating at a pace that even our science cannot grasp. Last week, a report was published that shows that Antarctica, hitherto regarded as the region of the cryosphere that was the slowest to be shedding ice mass, has overtaken Greenland as being the fastest contributor to rising oceanic sea levels... This can only happen on planet that is undergoing accelerated global warming. . Humans have around fifty years tops. Homo sapiens-sapiens, along with most other species, *will* become extinct before the close of this century. If not far sooner... And no one has mentioned the *wildcard* - war. . good question. The soils are the carbon sink. The herbivores mediate nutrient cycling via digestion of cellulose containing materials. so basically plant grows putting out exudates into the soil which contain carbon and facilitate the population growth of microbiota which use soil parent mineral material and photosynthates leached out by the plant via its root system to increase soil carbon. the plants indirectly and directly benefit from this microbial population via the minerals they make bioavailable from unavailable soil parent material (basically weathered down rocks that form sand silt and clay). however the important part Is grasslands which dump an enormous amount of carbon into the soil via aforementioned process when reaching maturity become lignified and the process(carbon cycling) slows down significantly (the plant is worried about seed production for the Next Generation not vegetative growth). enter the herbivores. Herbivores prune down the grassland and predigest the hard to break down cellulose for insects and micro fauna to turn the dung into a stable form of carbon such as Olmec, fulvic or humic acids. This eventually becomes a positive feedback loop and soil carbon begins to build to enormous levels such as what can be seen in the American Bread Basket where the Bison once roamed.

Here is why: Earth radiates at peak wavelength of 10 microns which corresponds to 59 degrees F, which is the average temperature of our planet. Most of this radiated energy( about 63 % of the total) is centered about 10 microns and within a couple of microns above and below 10 microns. That means whatever is absorbing the majority of the infrared radiated by Earth should have an peak absorption in the 8- 12 micron bandwidth. CO2 absorbs strongly at 2.7, 4.3, and 15 microns. Most gases including CO2 all absorb in very narrow bands around their peaks, no more than 2 microns on either side of the peak. This means that CO2 is absorbing only very negligible amounts of energy from the Earth. Coupled with that and the fact that Earth is not even close to being a perfect blackbody radiator(a perfect blackbody radiator does not exist in nature). The Earth is at best radiating with an emissivity of ..8 to .9. This means that the radiated energy of the Earth's surface is a smaller percentage of the total infrared held by the surface of the Earth. Furthermore, when CO2 absorbs a photon it vibrates over a period of time in the microsecond time range and then emits a different wavelength that is not in the CO2 absorption band. That photon has less than a 50% chance of being reabsorbed by the Earth since CO2 emits in a solid angle in all directions which includes back into space. What all this boils down to is that 1 molecule of CO2 is absorbing such extremely small amounts infrared that it's vibrations would be completely incapable of heating even a few molecules( say 4-5 molecules) of N2 and O2 around it to a temperature of even a fraction of a degree, let alone the 2500 molecules that surround it.

I should mention I received a reply from Simon Clark himself on another comment thread here. Since he's the go to man, figured I should repost his reply and mine for honesty's sake. Simon Clark Because it's not that simple - there are both positive and negative feedback loops. For example more CO2 -> warmer, wetter planet -> more photosynthesis from plants -> less CO2. But then at the same time more CO2 -> warmer, wetter planet -> more water vapour absorbing thermal wavelengths of radiation -> warmer planet. There are feedback loops all over the place, hence the need for complicated models! Zacharie Etienne Holy shit a reply from the man himself!! If there are both positive and negative feedback loops - that only means they would either cancel each other out, or they average out into one positive feedback loop, or a negative one. If it's positive or negative, the Earth would've been screwed from the get go regardless of humans. Therefore, when there's no human input, the Earth's CO2 levels must be self correcting , i.e. when CO2 levels are too high, the negative feedback loops have more punch, and when CO2 is too low, the positive feedback loops win over. Only this scenario would create an equilibrium allowing CO2 levels to remain stable over time, any other scenario would have CO2 levels spiral exponentially to either 0 or infinity due to effects of chaos. And if that's the case, then while an additional human input of CO2 will produce a temporary rise in temperature, eventually we will again find a natural equilibrium, because although we've increased the CO2 levels, because we've done that, the net negative feedback loops will become more pronounced, while the net positive feedback loops will diminish, and (as long as human CO2 input is constant), they'll be a point where the loops once again reach equilibrium. I can make an analogy with air resistance vs gravity. As you know, falling objects have air resistance, and the faster the velocity, the more air resistance. Therefore this is an example of a negative feedback loop, because if a falling object momentarily goes faster than the terminal velocity where air resistance and gravity are in equilibrium, then the object slows back down to terminal velocity. Likewise, if the object momentarily goes slower than the terminal velocity, gravity win over the air resistance, creating a positive feedback loop, and making the object speed back to terminal velocity. Any other universe where the object didn't have a positive feedback loop when going to slow AND a negative feedback loop when going to fast, would inevitably result in the object either coming to a complete stop or speeding up indefinitely. Now in this analogy, human input of CO2 is equivalent to reducing the object's surface area. By doing so, you'll have decreased the force of air resistance, making the object fall faster/have a higher terminal velocity. But the same positive/negative feedback loops apply, so although the object will temporarily fall faster, it will inevitably reach a new terminal velocity again, where the feedback loops cancel out and it's all ok.

+Zoe Phin No it's certainly possible CO2 has a positive feedback loop, but if that were true then the planet should have been very slowly yet exponentially heating up ever since it's creation well before humans - which is not the case. The reason a feedback loop doesn't violate the conservation of energy is because extra CO2 doesn't produce energy, it traps more of the sun's energy. What happens is the suns rays enter our atmosphere, hit the earth and bounce off. But what CO2 does is once the light rays go through, and bounce off the earth, they sort of "bounce back" off the CO2 back down to earth, like 2 mirrors facing each other. And the more CO2, the more efficiently the mirrors reflect. So it's not a perpetual motion machine scenario, it's just stopping the Earth from radiating so much of it's energy into space, like an oven, hence the warming.

+Ken Van de Burgt So what if it lags? That doesn't mean it can escape the feedback loop. All it means is that feedback loop takes very long to go round. +Ken Van de Burgt Yeah you just repeated what I said without my paradoxical conclusion. Here's my argument: 1) As CO2 levels increase, temperature also increases. 2) As temperature increases, sea temperature increases (duh). 3) As sea temperature increases, CO2 dissolution rates decrease. 4) As CO2 dissolution rates decrease, CO2 levels increase. Do you not see the contradiction here? By that logic, CO2 levels would NEVER be able to decrease. Because as soon as there's an increase for whatever reason, that amplifies the effects and makes it increase MORE and MORE! That means CO2 levels must have been increasing at an exponential rate throughout all of history!!! Or in other words, it'd be impossible for CO2 levels to be "stable". It's like if you were to stand a long stick perfectly straight up and let it go, it might stay up for a while, but as soon as it starts to lean even the slightest bit, that will cause it to lean even more, which will make it lean EVEN MORE etc. etc. and so the falling of the stick is IRREVERSIBLE even naturally!

CO2 levels drop because it gets absorbed by natural processes such as synthesis into plant matter or combining with calcium in sea water to form calcium carbonate. Too, when sea temperature goes up its ability to dissolve CO2 decreases ... just like a fizzy soda ... and it off gasses with the result of atmospheric CO2 levels going up. CO2 levels were getting close to the critical level of 150 ppm where life ceases to exist ... another million years or so and it would have got there if we hadn't started burning fossil fuels.
